notes.note: To **lift up**, take, or use the name of Yahweh (with emptiness, i.e. improperly) covers many sorts of speaking or invoking his name or making a claim to him or attempting to manipulate him or misrepresenting him. A broad word should be used in translation of this term.
Alternate translation: [You must not use the name of Yahweh your God]
Alternate translation: [carelessly] or [without proper respect]
If this double negative would be misunderstood in your language, you could translate it as a positive statement. Alternate translation: [I will certainly consider guilty]

bsb_verse_text: Remember the Sabbath day by keeping it holy.
ult_verse_text: Remember the Sabbath day, to set it apart to me.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [to make it holy to me] or [to consecrate it to me]

bsb_verse_text: Six days you shall labor and do all your work,
ult_verse_text: Six days you may labor and do all your work,

notes.note: Alternate translation: [your occupation] or [your livelihood]

bsb_verse_text: but the seventh day is a Sabbath to the LORD your God, on which you must not do any work—neither you, nor your son or daughter, nor your manservant or maidservant or livestock, nor the foreigner within your gates.
ult_verse_text: but the seventh day is a Sabbath for Yahweh your God. You shall not do any work, you or your son or your daughter, your male servant or your female servant or your cattle or the foreigner who is within your gates.

notes.note: Cities often had walls around them to keep out enemies, and gates for people to go in and out. Anyone who was inside the gates was part of the community. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [within your community] or [inside your city]

bsb_verse_text: For in six days the LORD made the heavens and the earth and the sea and all that is in them, but on the seventh day He rested. Therefore the LORD blessed the Sabbath day and set it apart as holy.
ult_verse_text: For in six days Yahweh made the heavens and earth, the sea, and everything that is in them, and rested on the seventh day. Therefore Yahweh blessed the Sabbath day and set it apart.

notes.note: If your language does not use ordinal numbers, you can use cardinal numbers here. Alternate translation: [on day seven]

bsb_verse_text: You shall not commit adultery.
ult_verse_text: You shall not commit adultery.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [You must not have sex with anyone other than your spouse]

bsb_verse_text: You shall not bear false witness against your neighbor.
ult_verse_text: You shall not testify false testimony against your neighbor.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [You must not speak a false report against your neighbor]

bsb_verse_text: You shall not covet your neighbor’s house. You shall not covet your neighbor’s wife, or his manservant or maidservant, or his ox or donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbor.”
ult_verse_text: You shall not covet the house of your neighbor; you shall not covet the wife of your neighbor or his male servant or his female servant or his ox or his donkey or anything that belongs to your neighbor.”

notes.note: Alternate translation: [You must not strongly want to have] or [You must not want to take]

bsb_verse_text: When all the people witnessed the thunder and lightning, the sounding of the ram’s horn, and the mountain enveloped in smoke, they trembled and stood at a distance.
ult_verse_text: All the people were seeing the thundering and the lightning and the sound of the horn and the mountain smoking. And the people saw it, and they trembled, and they stood from a distance.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [the smoky mountain]
Alternate translation: [and they shook with fear]
Alternate translation: [and stood far away]

bsb_verse_text: “Do not be afraid,” Moses replied. “For God has come to test you, so that the fear of Him may be before you, to keep you from sinning.”
ult_verse_text: And Moses said to the people, “Do not be afraid, for God has come to test you so that the fear of him may be above your faces and so that you do not sin.”

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠בַ⁠עֲב֗וּר תִּהְיֶ֧ה יִרְאָת֛⁠וֹ עַל־פְּנֵי⁠כֶ֖ם לְ⁠בִלְתִּ֥י תֶחֱטָֽאוּ
notes.note: Alternate translation: [so that you will honor him and not sin]

Here, **fear** is spoken of as something that could be **above their faces**. This means that they would be continually thinking about honoring God. It is similar to the image in [Exodus 13:16](../13/16.md). If your readers would not understand what this image means in this context, you could use an equivalent metaphor from your culture. Alternatively, you could express the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you will live always reverencing him]

bsb_verse_text: And the people stood at a distance as Moses approached the thick darkness where God was.
ult_verse_text: So the people stood far off, and Moses approached toward the thick darkness where God was.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [and Moses moved closer,]

bsb_verse_text: You are not to make any gods alongside Me; you are not to make for yourselves gods of silver or gold.
ult_verse_text: You shall not make alongside me—you shall not make gods of silver or gods of gold for yourselves.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [gods made out of silver or gold] or [idols made out of silver or gold]

bsb_verse_text: You are to make for Me an altar of earth, and sacrifice on it your burnt offerings and peace offerings, your sheep and goats and cattle. In every place where I cause My name to be remembered, I will come to you and bless you.
ult_verse_text: You shall make an altar of earth for me, and you shall sacrifice on it your burnt offerings, and peace offerings, sheep, and oxen. In every place where I cause my name to be remembered, I will come to you and bless you.

notes.note: The phrase **an altar of earth** means an altar made of materials from the ground, such as stone, soil, or clay.

Here, **name** is a metonym for God’s being. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [I cause myself to be remembered]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [I choose for you to remember me]

bsb_verse_text: And you must not go up to My altar on steps, lest your nakedness be exposed on it.’
ult_verse_text: And you shall not go up to my altar on steps, so that your nakedness is not exposed over it.’

notes.note: If you need to connect this statement more explicitly to the previous statements regarding building the alter, you could add a phrase about building steps. Alternate translation: [Do not build steps up to the altar and go up to it on those steps]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [so that you do not expose your nakedness over it]
Alternate translation: [your private parts]

bsb_verse_text: “These are the ordinances that you are to set before them:
ult_verse_text: And these are the ordinances that you shall set before their faces:

notes.note: Yahweh continues speaking to Moses. There is no quote break between chapters.
Alternate translation: [you must give] or [you must tell]
Here, **faces** represents the presence of the nation. Alternate translation: [before them]

bsb_verse_text: If you buy a Hebrew servant, he is to serve you for six years. But in the seventh year, he shall go free without paying anything.
ult_verse_text: ‘If you buy a Hebrew servant, he shall serve for six years, and in the seventh year he shall go free without paying anything.

notes.note: # General Information:\n\nHere Yahweh begins telling Moses his laws for the people of Israel.

This is the first of many hypothetical situations, introduced by “when” or **if,** which you will encounter over the next several chapters. See the Chapter 21 Introduction. You will need to translate these consistently in a manner that expresses that these situations have not happened.

bsb_verse_text: If he arrived alone, he is to leave alone; if he arrived with a wife, she is to leave with him.
ult_verse_text: If he came by himself, he shall go free by himself; if he is the husband of a wife, then his wife shall go free with him.

notes.note: What **by himself** means can be stated clearly. Some languages require that the additional condition, that he marries while a slave, be stated clearly. Alternate translation: [If he became a slave while he had no wife, and if he marries while he is a slave, the master need only free the man]
Alternate translation: [alone] or [without a wife]
Alternate translation: [if he was married when he became a slave] or [if he came as a married man]

bsb_verse_text: But if the servant declares, ‘I love my master and my wife and children; I do not want to go free,’
ult_verse_text: But if the servant plainly says, “I love my master, my wife, and my children; I shall not go out free,”

notes.note: Alternate translation: [makes a statement, saying]
Alternate translation: [I do not want my master to set me free]

bsb_verse_text: then his master is to bring him before the judges. And he shall take him to the door or doorpost and pierce his ear with an awl. Then he shall serve his master for life.
ult_verse_text: then his master shall bring him to God. He shall bring him to a door or to a doorpost, and his master shall bore his ear through with an awl. Then he shall serve him forever.

notes.note: The word for **God** at its most literal means “great ones.” Here it may have this basic meaning and refer to human judges or other leaders in Israel. It may also be a metonym and refer to the judges because they represent God to the people and have his authority. Texts other than the standard Hebrew text support this reading. See [Exodus 22:8–9](../22/08.md) for another example of this. Alternate translation: [the judges]
Alternate translation: [and … will put a hole in his ear]
An **awl** is a pointed tool used to make a hole
Alternate translation: [until the end of his life] or [until he dies]

bsb_verse_text: If she is displeasing in the eyes of her master who had designated her for himself, he must allow her to be redeemed. He has no right to sell her to foreigners, since he has broken faith with her.
ult_verse_text: If she is bad in the eyes of her master, who has appointed her for himself, then he shall cause her to be ransomed. He has no authority to sell her to a foreign people, since he has acted treacherously with her.

notes.note: This verse is the first of three possible situations between a master and his female slave.
Alternate translation: [has chosen her]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [then he must allow her father to buy her back]
Alternate translation: [since he has deceived her]

bsb_verse_text: And if he chooses her for his son, he must deal with her as with a daughter.
ult_verse_text: And if he appoints her for his son, he shall act toward her according to the custom of daughters.

notes.note: This verse is the second of three possible situations between a master and his female slave.
Alternate translation: [he decides that she is the one who will be his son’s wife]
Alternate translation: [he must do to her according to the manner in which daughters are customarily treated]

bsb_verse_text: If he takes another wife, he must not reduce the food, clothing, or marital rights of his first wife.
ult_verse_text: If he takes another to himself, he shall not diminish her food, her clothing, or her marital rights.

notes.note: This verse and the next are the third of three possible situations between a master and his female slave.

If this double negative would be misunderstood in your language, you could translate it as a positive statement. Alternate translation: [he must give the first wife the same food, clothing, and marital rights she had before]

This term only occurs here in the Bible. It probably means things that a husband must do for his wife. Most commentators believe it specifically means having sexual relations with her, possibly so that she can bear children. Alternate translation: [or her right to intimacy] or [or her childbearing rights]

bsb_verse_text: Whoever strikes and kills a man must surely be put to death.
ult_verse_text: Whoever strikes a man and he dies, he shall surely be put to death.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [Whoever attacks a man]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you must certainly execute that person] or [you must certainly kill that person]

bsb_verse_text: If, however, he did not lie in wait, but God allowed it to happen, then I will appoint for you a place where he may flee.
ult_verse_text: But if he did not lie in wait, but God let it happen by his hand, then I will appoint a place for you where he can flee.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [But if he did not plan to do it] or [But if he did not do it on purpose]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠שַׂמְתִּ֤י לְ⁠ךָ֙ מָק֔וֹם אֲשֶׁ֥ר יָנ֖וּס שָֽׁמָּ⁠ה
notes.note: If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express the purpose for choosing a place explicitly. Alternate translation: [I will choose a place to which he can run away to be safe]

bsb_verse_text: But if a man schemes and acts willfully against his neighbor to kill him, you must take him away from My altar to be put to death.
ult_verse_text: If a man willfully acts against his neighbor to kill him with cunning, then you shall take him from my altar for execution.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [after thinking carefully about it]
The word “him” refers to the one who killed his neighbor.
Alternate translation: [to execute him]

bsb_verse_text: Whoever strikes his father or mother must surely be put to death.
ult_verse_text: Whoever hits his father or his mother shall surely be put to death.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [If anyone hits his father or mother, you must surely put him to death] or [You must surely kill anyone who hits his father or mother]
Alternate translation: [certainly]

bsb_verse_text: Whoever kidnaps another man must be put to death, whether he sells him or the man is found in his possession.
ult_verse_text: Whoever steals a man—whether he sells him, or he is found in his hand—he shall surely be put to death.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you must kill that kidnapper]

bsb_verse_text: Anyone who curses his father or mother must surely be put to death.
ult_verse_text: Whoever acts contemptuously toward his father or his mother shall surely be put to death.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [You must surely kill anyone who curses his father or his mother]
The word translated **acts contemptuously** means the opposite of “honor” (as in the commandment to honor one’s parents). Alternate translation: [Whoever acts dishonorably toward]

bsb_verse_text: then the one who struck him shall go unpunished, as long as the other can get up and walk around outside with his staff. Nevertheless, he must compensate the man for his lost work and see that he is completely healed.
ult_verse_text: if he rises and walks about in the outdoors on his staff, then the striker is free. He only shall pay for his sitting and for his complete healing.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [he gets better]
Alternate translation: [then … is innocent]
This refers to a situation when someone cannot work to earn money. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [for the time he could not work]
Alternate translation: [and for his medical costs] or [and for his costs for healing]

bsb_verse_text: If a man strikes his manservant or maidservant with a rod, and the servant dies by his hand, he shall surely be punished.
ult_verse_text: And if a man hits his male servant or his female servant with a staff and he dies under his hand, he shall certainly be avenged.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [because of the injury] or [because the master hit him]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you must certainly punish that man]

bsb_verse_text: However, if the servant gets up after a day or two, the owner shall not be punished, since the servant is his property.
ult_verse_text: However, if he stands a day or two, he shall not be avenged, for he is his silver.

notes.note: A common view is that the loss of the valuable property, the slave, is itself a punishment. It may be that the master loses the slave for a time and also has to pay for his healing, or it may be that the slave dies after a few days. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that the servant was valuable to his master explicitly. Alternate translation: [because he has already lost his servant who was valuable to him] or [because he has already lost his servant’s work for a time and had to pay for his healing]

bsb_verse_text: If men who are fighting strike a pregnant woman and her child is born prematurely, but there is no further injury, he shall surely be fined as the woman’s husband demands and as the court allows.
ult_verse_text: And if men fight together and strike a pregnant woman and her children come out, but there is no serious injury, then he shall surely be fined as the husband of the woman puts on him, and he shall give according to the judges.

notes.note: It is not clear in the passage what happens to the child. The text is simply as in the ULT. Some have taken it to mean that the child dies because of premature birth, and the **serious injury** only relates to the woman. In this case, a fine is imposed for the loss of the child. However, the text could also mean that the child is born safely. A fine is still imposed because of the great danger to the two lives. Then the next few verses give consequences for any injury either to mother or child.
Alternate translation: [hurt]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you must certainly fine the guilty man] or [the guilty man must pay a fine]
Alternate translation: [what the judges decide]

bsb_verse_text: But if a serious injury results, then you must require a life for a life—
ult_verse_text: But if there is serious injury, then you shall give a life for a life,

notes.note: This means that if someone is hurt, the person who caused the hurt must be hurt in the same way. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [you must take the killer’s life for the murdered person’s life]

bsb_verse_text: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
ult_verse_text: an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, a hand for a hand, a foot for a foot,

notes.note: This means that if someone is hurt, the person who caused the hurt must be hurt in the same way. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [the striker’s eye for the injured person’s eye] (and repeated in like manner for each example throughout this and the next verse)

bsb_verse_text: If a man strikes and blinds the eye of his manservant or maidservant, he must let the servant go free as compensation for the eye.
ult_verse_text: And if a man hits the eye of his male servant or the eye of his female servant and destroys it, he shall let him go free in compensation for his eye.

notes.note: Here, **man** refers to the owner of a slave.
Alternate translation: [as payment for]

bsb_verse_text: If an ox gores a man or woman to death, the ox must surely be stoned, and its meat must not be eaten. But the owner of the ox shall not be held responsible.
ult_verse_text: And if an ox gores a man or a woman and he dies, the ox shall surely be stoned, and its flesh shall not be eaten, but the owner of the ox is innocent.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [an ox injures with its horns]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you must surely stone the ox to death]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and you must not eat its flesh]

bsb_verse_text: But if the ox has a habit of goring, and its owner has been warned yet does not restrain it, and it kills a man or woman, then the ox must be stoned and its owner must also be put to death.
ult_verse_text: But if the ox had a habit of goring in the past, and its owner was warned but did not keep it in, and it kills a man or a woman, the ox shall be stoned and its owner also shall be put to death.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state **its owner was warned** in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and someone warned its owner but he did not keep it in]
If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express the content of the warning explicitly. Alternate translation: [and its owner was warned that it gores but he did not keep it in]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and you must also kill its owner]

bsb_verse_text: If payment is demanded of him instead, he may redeem his life by paying the full amount demanded of him.
ult_verse_text: If a ransom is imposed on him, he shall give the ransom of his life, according to all that is imposed on him.

notes.orig_language_quote: אִם־כֹּ֖פֶר יוּשַׁ֣ת עָלָ֑י⁠ו וְ⁠נָתַן֙ פִּדְיֹ֣ן נַפְשׁ֔⁠וֹ כְּ⁠כֹ֥ל אֲשֶׁר־יוּשַׁ֖ת עָלָֽי⁠ו
notes.note: The text does not specify who will impose a ransom on the ox’s owner. Since other texts indicate that justice is retributive and performed by the dead person’s family, that is one option. Another option is that the judges will impose it. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express one of these explicitly.

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. However, you must make a decision regarding who is imposing the ransom or use an unspecified pronoun, if that is possible in your language (this second option would not make sense in English). Alternate translation: [If the judges impose a ransom on him … they impose on him]

bsb_verse_text: If the ox gores a son or a daughter, it shall be done to him according to the same rule.
ult_verse_text: If it gores a son or it gores a daughter, it shall be done to him according to this ordinance.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [it injures with its horns … it injures with its horns]
Here, **him** probably refers to the ox’s owner. Alternate translation: [to the owner]

bsb_verse_text: If the ox gores a manservant or maidservant, the owner must pay thirty shekels of silver to the master of that servant, and the ox must be stoned.
ult_verse_text: If the ox gores a male servant or a female servant, he shall give thirty silver shekels to the master, and the ox shall be stoned.

notes.note: In ancient times, a silver shekel weighed about 11 grams or about a third of an ounce. You could try to express the equivalent in terms of modern money values, but if you did, that could cause your Bible translation to become outdated and inaccurate, since those values can change over time. Instead, you could say something general like “30 silver coins” or give the equivalent weight or use the biblical term in the text and explain the weight in a footnote. Alternate translation: [330 grams of silver]
Because they are to kill the ox, the slave must have died. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [If an ox kills a male servant]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you must kill the ox by stoning it]

bsb_verse_text: If a man opens or digs a pit and fails to cover it, and an ox or a donkey falls into it,
ult_verse_text: And if a man opens a cistern or if a man digs a cistern and does not cover it and an ox or a donkey falls there,

notes.note: Alternate translation: [uncovers a hole in the ground] or [takes a cover off a hole in the ground]

bsb_verse_text: the owner of the pit shall make restitution; he must pay its owner, and the dead animal will be his.
ult_verse_text: the owner of the pit shall compensate. He shall cause silver to return to its owner, and the dead animal shall become his.

notes.note: The owner must be paid for the loss of his animal. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [he must pay the owner for the dead animal]
Alternate translation: [must make restitution]

The one who paid for the loss of the animal will become the owner of the dead animal and can do what he wants with it. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [and the dead animal will belong to the owner of the pit]

bsb_verse_text: If a man’s ox injures his neighbor’s ox and it dies, they must sell the live one and divide the proceeds; they also must divide the dead animal.
ult_verse_text: And if the ox of a man strikes the ox of another and it dies, then they shall sell the live ox and divide its silver, and they shall also divide the dead {ox}.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [and divide the money] or [and divide the money they receive]

bsb_verse_text: But if it was known that the ox had a habit of goring, yet its owner failed to restrain it, he shall pay full compensation, ox for ox, and the dead animal will be his.
ult_verse_text: If it was known that the ox had a habit of goring in the past, and its owner has not kept it in, he shall surely compensate ox for ox, and the dead animal shall become his own.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language.
Alternate translation: [the ox had gored other animals before]

This means that the owner did not keep his ox safely where it could not wander to hurt other animals. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [and its owner did not keep it inside a fence] or [and its owner did not tie it securely]

The owner of the ox that killed must give an ox to the man who lost his ox. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [the owner of the ox that killed must surely give a living ox to the owner of the ox that died]

bsb_verse_text: “If a man steals an ox or a sheep and slaughters or sells it, he must repay five oxen for an ox and four sheep for a sheep.
ult_verse_text: If a man steals an ox or a sheep and slaughters it or sells it, he shall compensate five cattle for the ox, and four sheep for the sheep.

notes.note: # General Information:\n\nYahweh continues telling Moses his laws for the people of Israel.

notes.orig_language_quote: כִּ֤י יִגְנֹֽב־אִישׁ֙ שׁ֣וֹר אוֹ־שֶׂ֔ה וּ⁠טְבָח֖⁠וֹ א֣וֹ מְכָר֑⁠וֹ
notes.note: This is the first of many hypothetical situations in this chapter, introduced by “when” or **if,** which you will encounter over the next several chapters. See the Chapter 22 Introduction. You will need to translate these consistently in a manner that expresses that these situations have not actually happened.
Alternate translation: [5 … and 4]

bsb_verse_text: If a thief is caught breaking in and is beaten to death, no one shall be guilty of bloodshed.
ult_verse_text: If a thief is found while breaking in, and he is struck and he dies, there is no bloodguilt for him.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [If anyone finds a thief while he is breaking in]
Alternate translation: [while using force to enter a house]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [if anyone strikes the thief so that he dies]
Alternate translation: [no one will be guilty of murdering him]

bsb_verse_text: But if it happens after sunrise, there is guilt for his bloodshed. A thief must make full restitution; if he has nothing, he himself shall be sold for his theft.
ult_verse_text: But if the sun has risen on him, there is bloodguilt for him.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [But if it is light before he breaks in] or [But if he breaks in and it is after sunrise]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you must sell him as a slave in order to pay for what he stole]

bsb_verse_text: If what was stolen is actually found alive in his possession—whether ox or donkey or sheep—he must pay back double.
ult_verse_text: If the stolen thing is actually found alive in his hand, from an ox to a donkey to a sheep, he shall compensate double.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [If they find that he still has the live animal that he stole]

The meaning of **compensate double** is not entirely clear. Most interpretations follow the UST, that is, two animals total must be given, the stolen one and one more. Some interpret double to mean the thief must pay two animals for every animal that he took, so three total. It would be best to leave double as ambiguous as possible. Alternate translation: [he must compensate twice what he stole]

bsb_verse_text: If a man grazes his livestock in a field or vineyard and allows them to stray so that they graze in someone else’s field, he must make restitution from the best of his own field or vineyard.
ult_verse_text: If a man causes his livestock to graze a field or vineyard and lets it go, and it grazes in the field of another, he shall compensate from the best of his field and from the best of his vineyard.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [causes to eat plants … and it eats plants]
**Livestock** is a collective singular noun that could refer to cows, goats, sheep, or basically any domesticated animals. In some languages you will need to translate it as a plural.
Alternate translation: [he must pay back the owner of that field]

bsb_verse_text: If a fire breaks out and spreads to thornbushes so that it consumes stacked or standing grain, or the whole field, the one who started the fire must make full restitution.
ult_verse_text: If a fire breaks out and spreads in thorns and stacked grain or the standing grain or a field is consumed, the fire starter shall surely compensate.

notes.note: Here, **breaks out** and **consumes** can be stated in active form or in another way that is natural in your language if your language does not use the passive form in this way. Alternate translation: [If someone starts a fire, and it spreads in thorns, and it consumes]
Alternate translation: [and moves along the ground through dry plants]
This is grain that has been cut and tied in bundles. Alternate translation: [bundled grain] or [harvested grain]
This is grain that has not been cut, but it is ready to be harvested. Alternate translation: [the grain still growing in the field]

bsb_verse_text: If a man gives his neighbor money or goods for safekeeping and they are stolen from the neighbor’s house, the thief, if caught, must pay back double.
ult_verse_text: If a man gives silver or goods to his neighbor for safekeeping, and if it is stolen from the house of the man, if the thief is found, he shall compensate double.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [to watch over it] or [to keep it safe]
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [if someone steals it]
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [if you find the thief]

bsb_verse_text: If the thief is not found, the owner of the house must appear before the judges to determine whether he has taken his neighbor’s property.
ult_verse_text: If the thief is not found, then the owner of the house shall be brought to God, whether or not he has stretched out his hand against the property of his neighbor.

notes.orig_language_quote: אִם־לֹ֤א יִמָּצֵא֙ הַ⁠גַּנָּ֔ב וְ⁠נִקְרַ֥ב בַּֽעַל־הַ⁠בַּ֖יִת אֶל־הָֽ⁠אֱלֹהִ֑ים
notes.note: You may need to translate these in an active voice if your language does not use passive in this way. Alternate translation: [If no one finds the thief, bring the owner of the house to God]

The word for **God** at its most literal means “great ones.” Here and in the [next verse](../22/09.md) it may have this basic meaning and refer to human judges or other leaders in Israel. It may also be a metonym and refer to the judges because they represent God to the people and have his authority. See [Exodus 21:6](../21/06.md) for another example of this. Alternate translation: [the judges]
This is an idiom for stealing. If you have a way of saying this in your language, you can use it here. Alternate translation: [he has stolen his neighbor’s property]

bsb_verse_text: In all cases of illegal possession of an ox, a donkey, a sheep, a garment, or any lost item that someone claims, ‘This is mine,’ both parties shall bring their cases before the judges. The one whom the judges find guilty must pay back double to his neighbor.
ult_verse_text: Concerning every matter of transgression, concerning an ox, concerning a donkey, concerning a sheep, concerning clothing, concerning every lost property about which someone says, “Surely this is it,” the matter of both parties shall come to God. Whomever God declares guilty shall compensate his neighbor double.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [dispute of … the dispute of]
Alternate translation: [This is mine] or [This is my missing property]

The word used here for **God**, at its most literal, means “great ones.” Here and in the [previous verse](../22/08.md) it may have this basic meaning and refer to human judges or other leaders in Israel. It may also be a metonym and refer to the judges because they represent God to the people and have his authority. See [Exodus 21:6](../21/06.md) for another example of this. Alternate translation: [the judges]

bsb_verse_text: If a man gives a donkey, an ox, a sheep, or any other animal to be cared for by his neighbor, but it dies or is injured or stolen while no one is watching,
ult_verse_text: If a man gives to his neighbor a donkey or an ox or a sheep or any animal to keep, and it dies or is hurt or is carried away without a witness,

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language, as modeled in the UST.

Here, **carried away** means that it is not a thief but a wild animal that takes the ox or sheep away (to eat it). See [22:12](../22/12.md) for cases where the animal is stolen while in another’s care.

bsb_verse_text: an oath before the LORD shall be made between the parties to determine whether or not the man has taken his neighbor’s property. The owner must accept the oath and require no restitution.
ult_verse_text: there shall be an oath of Yahweh between both of them, whether or not he stretched out his hand against the property of his neighbor. Its owner must accept, and he shall not compensate.

notes.orig_language_quote: שְׁבֻעַ֣ת יְהוָ֗ה תִּהְיֶה֙ בֵּ֣ין שְׁנֵי⁠הֶ֔ם & וְ⁠לָקַ֥ח בְּעָלָ֖י⁠ו
notes.note: Only the man who is accused of stealing the animal must swear the oath. The owner of the lost animal must accept the oath that has been sworn. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the man who was caring for the animal must swear an oath before Yahweh … and the owner must accept that oath]

bsb_verse_text: But if the animal was actually stolen from the neighbor, he must make restitution to the owner.
ult_verse_text: But if it was truly stolen from him, he shall compensate its owner.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [But if someone stole the animal from him]

bsb_verse_text: If the animal was torn to pieces, he shall bring it as evidence; he need not make restitution for the torn carcass.
ult_verse_text: If it was truly torn, he shall bring it as evidence. He shall not compensate for what was torn.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [But if a wild beast tore the animal in pieces]

bsb_verse_text: If a man borrows an animal from his neighbor and it is injured or dies while its owner is not present, he must make full restitution.
ult_verse_text: If a man borrows from his neighbor and it is injured or dies without the owner with it, he shall surely compensate.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [must certainly repay with another animal] or [must certainly pay the owner for the animal]
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language, as modeled in the UST.

bsb_verse_text: If the owner was present, no restitution is required. If the animal was rented, the fee covers the loss.
ult_verse_text: If its owner was with it, he shall not compensate; if it was for hire, it came for its hiring fee.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [if someone rented the animal]

The one who borrowed the animal will not have to pay the owner anything more than the hiring or rental fee. This fee will pay for the loss of the animal. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [the money that someone paid to rent the animal will cover the loss of the animal]
Alternate translation: [for its rental fee] or [for the money paid to rent the animal]

bsb_verse_text: If a man seduces a virgin who is not pledged in marriage and sleeps with her, he must pay the full dowry for her to be his wife.
ult_verse_text: If a man seduces a virgin who is not engaged, and if he lies with her, he shall surely pay her bride price to make her his wife.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [If a man persuades a virgin who is not engaged that she wants to lie with him]
Alternate translation: [not promised to be married]

Lying with someone refers to having sex. This is a polite way of referring to something unpleasant. If this would be misunderstood in your language, use a different polite way of referring to this or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [if he has sex with her]
The **bride price** was money paid to the family to compensate for the loss of their daughter.

bsb_verse_text: If her father absolutely refuses to give her to him, the man still must pay an amount comparable to the bridal price of a virgin.
ult_verse_text: If her father completely refuses to give her to him, he shall weigh out silver equal to the bride price of virgins.

notes.note: Here, **him** and **he** refer back to the man who seduced the virgin.

bsb_verse_text: Whoever lies with an animal must surely be put to death.
ult_verse_text: Any lier with an animal shall surely be put to death.

notes.note: This refers to sexual relations. This is a polite way of referring to something unpleasant. If this would be misunderstood in your language, use a different polite way of referring to this or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [Whoever has sexual relations with an animal]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state **be put to death** in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [You must surely execute whoever lies with an animal]

bsb_verse_text: If anyone sacrifices to any god other than the LORD alone, he must be set apart for destruction.
ult_verse_text: A sacrificer to the gods except to Yahweh alone shall be completely destroyed.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation (placed at the beginning of the sentence): [You must completely destroy]

bsb_verse_text: You must not exploit or oppress a foreign resident, for you yourselves were foreigners in the land of Egypt.
ult_verse_text: You shall not wrong a sojourner and you shall not oppress him, for you were sojourners in the land of Egypt.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [You must not mistreat] or [You must not cheat]

The Israelites are called to remember their previous condition, that they lived as foreign guests in Egypt. They came first to avoid the famine in Jacob and Joseph’s time and were dependent on Egyptian hospitality. Later they were wronged and oppressed, and they are not to do that to those who sojourn with them. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [for you were wronged and oppressed as sojourners in the land of Egypt] or [for you also depended on hospitality while you lived as sojourners in Egypt]

bsb_verse_text: You must not mistreat any widow or orphan.
ult_verse_text: You shall not afflict any widow or fatherless child.

notes.note: If this double negative would be misunderstood in your language, you could translate it as a positive statement. Alternate translation: [You must treat all widows and fatherless children fairly]
Alternate translation: [woman whose husband has died]
Alternate translation: [or child with no parents]

bsb_verse_text: My anger will be kindled, and I will kill you with the sword; then your wives will become widows and your children will be fatherless.
ult_verse_text: and my nose will burn, and I will kill you with the sword; your wives will become widows, and your sons will become fatherless.

notes.note: This is an idiom meaning that Yahweh will be angry. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [and I will became very angry]

To be killed **with the sword** is a metonym that means a person will die violently, perhaps while fighting in a war. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [violently]

bsb_verse_text: If you lend money to one of My people among you who is poor, you must not act as a creditor to him; you are not to charge him interest.
ult_verse_text: If you lend silver to my people, the poor with you, you shall not be like a creditor to him—you shall not put interest on him.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [like one who lends money]
Alternate translation: [you must not charge him extra money for borrowing] or [you must not charge him extra money for the loan]

bsb_verse_text: because his cloak is the only covering he has for his body. What else will he sleep in? And if he cries out to Me, I will hear, for I am compassionate.
ult_verse_text: for it is his only covering; it is his clothing for his skin. In what will he lie down? And it will be when he cries to me, that I will hear him, for I am gracious.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [is his only coat] or [is his only garment to keep him warm]

This question adds emphasis. If you would not use a rhetorical question for this purpose in your language, you could translate his words as a statement or an exclamation and communicate the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [He will have nothing to wear while he sleeps!]

bsb_verse_text: You must not blaspheme God or curse the ruler of your people.
ult_verse_text: You shall not act contemptuously toward God, and you shall not curse a ruler of your people.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [Do not insult God] or [Do not speak evil about God]
Alternate translation: [and do not ask God to do bad things to your ruler]

bsb_verse_text: You must not hold back offerings from your granaries or vats. You are to give Me the firstborn of your sons.
ult_verse_text: You shall not hold back from your full harvest or your presses.

notes.note: If this double negative would be misunderstood in your language, you could translate it as a positive statement. Alternate translation: [You must bring all of your offerings]

bsb_verse_text: You shall do likewise with your cattle and your sheep. Let them stay with their mothers for seven days, but on the eighth day you are to give them to Me.
ult_verse_text: You shall do the same to your ox and to your sheep. Seven days it will be with its mother; on the eighth day you shall give it to me.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [7]
If your language does not use ordinal numbers, you can use cardinal numbers here. Alternate translation: [on day 8]

bsb_verse_text: You are to be My holy people. You must not eat the meat of a mauled animal found in the field; you are to throw it to the dogs.
ult_verse_text: And you shall be men of holiness to me. And you shall not eat animal-torn-in-the-field meat. You shall throw it to the dogs.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **holiness**, you can express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [And you shall be holy men to men]

bsb_verse_text: “You shall not spread a false report. Do not join the wicked by being a malicious witness.
ult_verse_text: You shall not take up a report of emptiness. You shall not put your hand with the wicked to be a witness of violence.

notes.note: # General Information:\n\nYahweh continues telling Moses his laws for the people of Israel.

If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **report** and **emptiness**, you can express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [You must not report emptily] or [You must not report falsely]
Alternate translation: [a false testimony]

Here, to **put your hand with the wicked** means to support the lies that he is telling in order to harm someone else. The image is of putting out your hand to help him, to make him stronger than he would be on his own. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [You must not assist the wicked]

Here, **violence** can also mean “wrong.” Either way, it means to harm another person by committing injustice (violence to justice) by lying. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [a false witness]

bsb_verse_text: You shall not follow the crowd in wrongdoing. When you testify in a lawsuit, do not pervert justice by siding with the crowd.
ult_verse_text: You shall not follow a crowd into evil, nor shall you testify on legal matters to turn aside behind the crowd that turns aside.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [and you also must not speak]

This is a metaphor that describes one’s agreeing with a group of people as if he actually walked behind that group. If your readers would not understand what this image means in this context, you could use an equivalent metaphor from your culture. Alternatively, you could express the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [You must not do the evil that the crowd wants] or [You must not agree with the majority for evil]

The phrase “from justice” is omitted twice but should be understood in both cases. If it would be helpful in your language, you could supply these words from the context. Alternate translation: [to turn aside from justice … that turns aside from justice]
Here, **to turn aside** means to do illegal or immoral actions that result in an unjust ruling. Alternate translation: [to pervert justice … that perverts justice]

bsb_verse_text: You shall not deny justice to the poor in their lawsuits.
ult_verse_text: You shall not turn aside justice for your poor in his lawsuit.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [Do not decide to treat a poor man unjustly in legal matters]
Here, **in his lawsuit** refers to any matter that a court decides.

bsb_verse_text: Stay far away from a false accusation. Do not kill the innocent or the just, for I will not acquit the guilty.
ult_verse_text: You shall be far from a word of deception, and you shall not kill the innocent or righteous, for I will not justify the wicked.

notes.note: Here distance is used to tell the Israelites to have no part in deception. If your readers would not understand what this image means in this context, you could use an equivalent metaphor from your culture. Alternatively, you could express the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Do not speak deceptively] or [Do not join a false matter]

These two terms mean very similar things, both of which contrast with **the wicked** later in the verse. If your language does not use repetition in this way, you can combine these phrases. Alternate translation: [and … the person who has not done anything wrong or the person who always does what is right] or [and … the person who does right and not wrong]
Alternate translation: [I will not find the wicked not guilty] or [I will not say that a wicked person is innocent]

bsb_verse_text: Do not accept a bribe, for a bribe blinds those who see and twists the words of the righteous.
ult_verse_text: And you shall not take a bribe, for the bribe blinds the clear-sighted, and it perverts the words of the righteous.

notes.orig_language_quote: כִּ֤י הַ⁠שֹּׁ֨חַד֙ יְעַוֵּ֣ר פִּקְחִ֔ים וִֽ⁠יסַלֵּ֖ף דִּבְרֵ֥י צַדִּיקִֽים
notes.note: Here, a “bribe” is described as if it could take action itself that negatively affects justice. If this might be confusing for your readers, you could express this meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [for if you do, an evil person can give money to blind the clear-sighted and to pervert the words of the righteous]

notes.orig_language_quote: כִּ֤י הַ⁠שֹּׁ֨חַד֙ יְעַוֵּ֣ר פִּקְחִ֔ים וִֽ⁠יסַלֵּ֖ף דִּבְרֵ֥י צַדִּיקִֽים
notes.note: To **blind the clear-sighted** is a metaphor that means causing those who know what is right to act like they do not. And **perverts the words of the righteous** could mean causes those who would speak the truth (in court) to lie or causes the judge to give an evil judgment or causes those listening to **the words of the righteous** to choose to act as if they had heard something different. If your readers would not understand what this image means in this context, you could use an equivalent metaphor from your culture. Alternatively, you could express the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [for a bribe causes those who understand the right thing to do not to do it and causes good men to speak lies]

bsb_verse_text: Do not oppress a foreign resident, since you yourselves know how it feels to be foreigners; for you were foreigners in the land of Egypt.
ult_verse_text: And you shall not oppress a foreigner, since you yourself know the soul of the foreigner, for you were foreigners in the land of Egypt.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [the feelings of the foreigner]

bsb_verse_text: For six years you are to sow your land and gather its produce,
ult_verse_text: And six years you shall sow your land and gather its produce.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [the food its plants produce]
Alternate translation: [And 6]

bsb_verse_text: but in the seventh year you must let it rest and lie fallow, so that the poor among your people may eat from the field and the wild animals may consume what they leave. Do the same with your vineyard and olive grove.
ult_verse_text: But the seventh you shall let it drop and leave it alone, and the poor of your people shall eat. And the living things of the field shall eat the reminder. You shall do thus to your vineyard and to your olive orchard.

notes.note: If your language does not use ordinal numbers, you can use cardinal numbers here. Alternate translation: [But year 7]
This means to leave the land fallow, that is, in its natural state, unplowed, unplanted, not used to grow food.

The poor can eat any food that grows on its own in a field that is not cultivated. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [so the poor among your people may harvest and eat any food that grows on its own in that field]

bsb_verse_text: For six days you are to do your work, but on the seventh day you must cease, so that your ox and your donkey may rest and the son of your maidservant may be refreshed, as well as the foreign resident.
ult_verse_text: Six days you shall do your work, and on the seventh day you shall rest so that your ox and your donkey may rest, and the son of your female slave and the sojourner may be refreshed.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [your work animals]
Alternate translation: [6]
If your language does not use ordinal numbers, you can use cardinal numbers here. Alternate translation: [and on day 7]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and the son of your female slave and the sojourner may refresh themselves]

bsb_verse_text: Pay close attention to everything I have said to you. You must not invoke the names of other gods; they must not be heard on your lips.
ult_verse_text: You shall take heed to everything that I have said to you. You shall not mention the names of other gods, nor let them be heard on your mouth.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [Do] or [Obey]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠שֵׁ֨ם אֱלֹהִ֤ים אֲחֵרִים֙ לֹ֣א תַזְכִּ֔ירוּ לֹ֥א יִשָּׁמַ֖ע עַל־פִּֽי⁠ךָ
notes.note: These two instructions mean almost the same thing. If saying the same thing twice might be confusing for your readers, you can combine the phrases into one. Alternate translation: [Be sure never to speak the names of other gods]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠שֵׁ֨ם אֱלֹהִ֤ים אֲחֵרִים֙ לֹ֣א תַזְכִּ֔ירוּ לֹ֥א יִשָּׁמַ֖ע עַל־פִּֽי⁠ךָ
notes.note: These parallel phrases probably mean praying to other gods. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [Do not pray to other gods, never let me hear you do that]
To be **on your mouth** means to speak. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [nor speak them]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Also see previous note. Alternate translation: [nor speak them so someone could hear them]

bsb_verse_text: Three times a year you are to celebrate a feast to Me.
ult_verse_text: You shall celebrate me three times every year.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [3]

bsb_verse_text: You are to keep the Feast of Unleavened Bread as I commanded you: At the appointed time in the month of Abib you are to eat unleavened bread for seven days, because that was the month you came out of Egypt. No one may appear before Me empty-handed.
ult_verse_text: You shall keep the Festival of Unleavened Bread. You shall eat unleavened bread seven days, as I commanded you, at the appointed time, the month of Aviv, for in it you came out from Egypt. And you shall not appear at my face empty-handed.

notes.note: **Aviv** is the name of the first month of the Hebrew calendar. Aviv is during the last part of March and the first part of April on Western calendars. See how you translated this in [Exodus 13:4](../13/04.md). You could convert the Hebrew day and month into an approximate date on the calendar that your culture uses. However, the Jews used a lunar calendar, so if you use a solar calendar, the date will be different every year and the translation will not be entirely accurate. So you may just want to give the number of the day and the name of the month on the Hebrew calendar, and say approximately what time of year that is on your calendar in a footnote.
Alternate translation: [7]

Understatement is used here to emphasize that the Israelites must bring a suitable offering to Yahweh. If this double negative would be misunderstood in your language, you could translate it as a positive statement. Alternate translation: [Every single time you worship me you must bring an offering]

bsb_verse_text: You are also to keep the Feast of Harvest with the firstfruits of the produce from what you sow in the field. And keep the Feast of Ingathering at the end of the year, when you gather your produce from the field.
ult_verse_text: And {you shall keep} the Festival of the Harvest, {bringing} the first fruits of your labors which you sowed in the field.

notes.note: Elsewhere this is called the “Festival of Weeks.” See [Exodus 34:22](../34/22.md) and [Deuteronomy 16:9](../../deu/16/09.md) and following.

This festival celebrated the final harvesting of all the crops for the year. This festival was also known as the Festival of Shelters or the Festival of Booths. The idea came from the practice of the farmers living in temporary booths, or huts, out in the fields to guard the crop as it ripened. See [Deuteronomy 16:13](../../deu/16/13.md). Alternate translation: [And the Festival of the Ingathering]

The phrase **in the exiting of the year** means at the end of the year. The year is pictured as something that is leaving. If your readers would not understand what this image means in this context, you could use an equivalent metaphor from your culture. Alternatively, you could express the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [as the year goes out]

bsb_verse_text: Three times a year all your males are to appear before the Lord GOD.
ult_verse_text: Three times in a year, all your males shall appear to the face of the Lord Yahweh.

notes.note: Here, to **appear to the face of the Lord Yahweh** means to gather to worship. **To the face** is a metonym for Yahweh’s presence, referring to worship. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [must come to worship the Lord Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: Behold, I am sending an angel before you to protect you along the way and to bring you to the place I have prepared.
ult_verse_text: Behold, I am about to send an angel before your face to guard you on the way and to bring you to the place that I have prepared.

notes.note: This means “in front of you.” Alternate translation: [in front of you]

bsb_verse_text: Pay attention to him and listen to his voice; do not defy him, for he will not forgive rebellion, since My Name is in him.
ult_verse_text: Be guarded from his face and listen to his voice. Do not cause bitterness in him, for he will not bear with your transgressions, for my name is within him.

notes.note: This means to respect him; **from his face** refers to his person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [Show respect to him]
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Pay attention to him]

There are two reasons given for the instruction **do not cause bitterness in him**. They are connected in such a way that you could say: “Because my name is within him, he will not forgive your transgressions; therefore, do not cause bitterness in him.” The relation of the **name** and **forgiveness** is not explicit. Alternate translation: [If you provoke him, he will not pardon your sins, for my name is within him]
Here, **name** refers to God’s authority. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [he has my authority]
Here, **voice** represents what the angel says. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and obey what he says]

bsb_verse_text: But if you will listen carefully to his voice and do everything I say, I will be an enemy to your enemies and a foe to your foes.
ult_verse_text: For if you indeed heed his voice and do everything that I speak, then I will be an enemy to your enemies and I will be an adversary to your adversaries.

notes.note: Here, **voice** represents what the angel says. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [if you carefully obey what he says]
These two phrases mean the same thing and are used for emphasis. If saying the same thing twice might be confusing for your readers, you can combine the phrases into one.

bsb_verse_text: For My angel will go before you and bring you into the land of the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Canaanites, Hivites, and Jebusites, and I will annihilate them.
ult_verse_text: For my angel will go before your face and bring you to the Amorites and the Hittites and the Perizzites and the Canaanites, the Hivites and the Jebusites. I will annihilate them.

notes.note: This phrase, **before your face**, means “in front of you.” Alternate translation: [in front of you]

bsb_verse_text: You must not bow down to their gods or serve them or follow their practices. Instead, you are to demolish them and smash their sacred stones to pieces.
ult_verse_text: You shall not bow down to their gods, and you shall not serve them, and you shall not do as they do. For you shall completely overthrow them and completely smash their stone pillars.

notes.note: The Israelites must not live as the people who worship other gods. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [and you must not live as the people live who worship those gods]

bsb_verse_text: So you shall serve the LORD your God, and He will bless your bread and your water. And I will take away sickness from among you.
ult_verse_text: And you shall serve Yahweh your God, and he will bless your bread and your water. And I will remove sickness from among you.

notes.note: Here, **your bread and your water** is a merism that means food and drink. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and he will bless your food and drink] or [and he will bless you by giving you food and drink]
Yahweh switched between the first and third pronoun to refer to himself. Here, both **he** and **I** refer to Yahweh.

bsb_verse_text: No woman in your land will miscarry or be barren; I will fulfill the number of your days.
ult_verse_text: There will not be a miscarriage or a barren woman in your land. I will fulfill the number of your days.

notes.note: If this double negative would be misunderstood in your language, you could translate it as a positive statement. Alternate translation: [Every woman will be able to become pregnant and give birth to healthy babies]
to have a pregnancy end early and unexpectedly, resulting in the death of the baby
This is an idiom that means to live a long time. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [I will give you a long life]

bsb_verse_text: I will send My terror ahead of you and throw into confusion every nation you encounter. I will make all your enemies turn and run.
ult_verse_text: I will send my terror before your face, and I will confuse all of the people into whom you will go, and I will give the back of the neck of all of your enemies to you.

notes.note: This means “ahead of you.” Alternate translation: [before you]

This is an idiom meaning that the enemies will turn and run away (showing the Israelites the backs of their necks). If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [and I will make all of your enemies flee]

bsb_verse_text: I will send the hornet before you to drive the Hivites and Canaanites and Hittites out of your way.
ult_verse_text: And I will send the hornet before your face, and it will drive out the Hivites, Canaanites, and the Hittites from before your face.

notes.note: This means “ahead of you.” Alternate translation: [before you … from before you]
The **hornet** is a flying insect that can sting people and cause pain.

Here, **hornet** is used in the singular but refers to a large group of the flying, stinging insects. **It** agrees in number with **hornet**. It may be necessary to translate as a plural. Alternate translation: [hornets … and they will drive out]

bsb_verse_text: I will not drive them out before you in a single year; otherwise the land would become desolate and wild animals would multiply against you.
ult_verse_text: I will not drive them out from before your face in one year, lest the land become desolate and the animals of the field become too many for you.

notes.note: This means “ahead of you.” Alternate translation: [from before you]
If it would be helpful to your readers, you could make the rest of the idea explicit. Alternate translation: [lest the land become desolate because no one would be living in the land]

bsb_verse_text: Little by little I will drive them out ahead of you, until you become fruitful and possess the land.
ult_verse_text: I will drive them out little by little from before your face until you become fruitful and possess the land.

notes.note: This means “ahead of you.” Alternate translation: [from before you]

bsb_verse_text: And I will establish your borders from the Red Sea to the Sea of the Philistines, and from the desert to the Euphrates. For I will deliver the inhabitants into your hand, and you will drive them out before you.
ult_verse_text: And I will set your borders from the Sea of Reeds to the sea of the Philistines, and from the wilderness to the river. For I will give the inhabitants of the land into your hand. And you will drive them out from before your faces.

notes.note: This means “ahead of you.” Alternate translation: [from before you]

bsb_verse_text: They must not remain in your land, lest they cause you to sin against Me. For if you serve their gods, it will surely be a snare to you.”
ult_verse_text: They shall not live in your land, lest they cause you to sin against me; for you will serve their gods. Surely it will become a snare for you.’”

notes.note: This means worshiping other gods will lead the people of Israel to certain destruction, as if they were an animal caught in a hunter’s trap. It could also be saying that leaving the other people around will make it so that the Israelites see the other people’s worship and are lured (like in a trap) into worshiping the other gods, which is a sin against Yahweh. If your readers would not understand what this image means in this context, you could use an equivalent metaphor from your culture. Alternatively, you could express the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Worshiping them will surely destroy you]

bsb_verse_text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Come up to the LORD—you and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of Israel’s elders—and you are to worship at a distance.
ult_verse_text: And he said to Moses, “Come up to Yahweh—you and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu and seventy from the elders of Israel, and you shall bow down from a distance.

notes.note: A new scene begins here, which may need to be marked in a certain way in your language.
**Nadab and Abihu** are men’s names. See how you translated these names in [Exodus 6:23](../06/23.md).
Yahweh refers to himself in the third person. If this is confusing in your language, you may use the first person. Alternate translation: [to me]
Alternate translation: [and 70]
Here, after **bow down,** “to me” is implied. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [and you shall bow down to me]

bsb_verse_text: Moses alone shall approach the LORD, but the others must not come near. And the people may not go up with him.”
ult_verse_text: And Moses alone shall come near to Yahweh, and they shall not come near, and the people shall not come up with him.”

notes.note: Here, **they** refers to all the other people mentioned in [24:1](../24/01.md). Alternate translation: [and Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and the elders]
Yahweh refers to himself in the third person. If this is confusing in your language, you may use the first person. Alternate translation: [to me]

bsb_verse_text: When Moses came and told the people all the words and ordinances of the LORD, they all responded with one voice: “All the words that the LORD has spoken, we will do.”
ult_verse_text: And Moses went and recounted to the people all of the words of Yahweh and all of the ordinances. And all of the people answered with one voice and said, “We will do all the things that Yahweh has spoken.”

notes.note: Verses 3–8 tell of a different scene than the rest of the chapter, which may need to be marked in a certain way in your language. It seems that there were some preparations needed before Moses and the elders could go up to meet Yahweh.
See [Exodus 19:8](../19/08.md) for how you translated a very similar event.

Here, **with one voice** is an idiom that means the people were in complete agreement. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [together] or [in agreement]

bsb_verse_text: And Moses wrote down all the words of the LORD. Early the next morning he got up and built an altar at the base of the mountain, along with twelve pillars for the twelve tribes of Israel.
ult_verse_text: And Moses wrote all of the words of Yahweh.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [at the base of the mountain]
Alternate translation: [and 12 … according to the 12]

bsb_verse_text: Then he took the Book of the Covenant and read it to the people, who replied, “All that the LORD has spoken we will do, and we will be obedient.”
ult_verse_text: And he took the Book of the Covenant and read it aloud in the ears of the people. And they said, “We will do and hear all that Yahweh has spoken.”

notes.note: Here, **book** does not mean something in our modern format. It was likely a piece of papyrus (an early form of paper made from reeds) or animal skin that rolled up. Alternate translation: [the Covenant he had written down]

bsb_verse_text: So Moses took the blood, splattered it on the people, and said, “This is the blood of the covenant that the LORD has made with you in accordance with all these words.”
ult_verse_text: And Moses took the blood and sprinkled it onto the people. And he said, “Behold! the blood of the covenant that Yahweh has cut with you according to all of these words.”

notes.note: This refers to **the blood** that Moses had put into the bowls. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly.

**These words** refers to what Moses just read aloud to them, that is, Yahweh’s commands. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [which I just read aloud to you and you agreed to]

bsb_verse_text: Then Moses went up with Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel,
ult_verse_text: And Moses and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu and seventy from the elders of Israel went up.

notes.note: A new scene begins with this verse, which may need to be marked in a certain way in your language. Here the narrative is connected to [24:2](../24/02.md).
**Nadab and Abihu** are men’s names. See how you translated these names in [Exodus 6:23](../06/23.md).
The men **went up** the mountain. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly.

bsb_verse_text: and they saw the God of Israel. Under His feet was a work like a pavement made of sapphire, as clear as the sky itself.
ult_verse_text: And they saw the God of Israel. And under his feet was like tile made of sapphire, and its substance was as the sky in purity.

notes.note: **And under his feet** speaks of God as if he had human feet. If this might be confusing for your readers, you could express this meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And below where God was]
a hard surface for walking or riding

A **sapphire** is a gemstone that is blue in color. If there is a blue gemstone that your people are familiar with, you may use it here, as the exact gemstone is not certain. You may also describe it. Alternate translation: [a blue gemstone]

The point of this comparison is the blueness of the tile. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent comparison or express this meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and it was blue like the sky]

bsb_verse_text: But God did not lay His hand on the nobles of Israel; they saw Him, and they ate and drank.
ult_verse_text: And he did not send out his hand to the leaders of the sons of Israel. And they saw God, and they ate and drank.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אֶל־אֲצִילֵי֙ בְּנֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל לֹ֥א שָׁלַ֖ח יָד֑⁠וֹ
notes.note: Here, **his hand** refers to his judgement. This means that God did not harm the leaders. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [God did not harm the Israelite leaders]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אֶל־אֲצִילֵי֙ בְּנֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל לֹ֥א שָׁלַ֖ח יָד֑⁠וֹ
notes.note: What would be expected is that they would die if they saw God. The Israelite elders ability to see God and live is unexpected. Be sure your translation conveys that. Alternate translation: [However, he did not send out his hand to the leaders of the sons of Israel]

bsb_verse_text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Come up to Me on the mountain and stay here, so that I may give you the tablets of stone, with the law and commandments I have written for their instruction.”
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh said to Moses, “Come up to me to the mountain and be there. And I will give you the tablets of stone and the law and the commandments that I have written to teach them.”

notes.note: This means so that Moses and the other Israelite leaders could teach the laws and commandments to the Israelite people. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly.

bsb_verse_text: So Moses set out with Joshua his attendant and went up on the mountain of God.
ult_verse_text: And Moses and his servant Joshua got up, and Moses went up to the mountain of God.

notes.note: **Joshua** is introduced here again. Use the natural form in your language for reintroducing a character.

The word translated **servant** here is usually associated with a higher position, like a government minister. Avoid using a word that implies a lower-class serving role. Alternate translation: [and Joshua his assistant]

bsb_verse_text: And he said to the elders, “Wait here for us until we return to you. Aaron and Hur are here with you. Whoever has a dispute can go to them.”
ult_verse_text: And he had said to the elders, “Wait for us in this place until we return to you. And behold! Aaron and Hur are with you; Whoever is a master of words may come near to them.”

notes.note: The structure of the Hebrew indicates but does not require that this speech by Moses happened before [24:13](../24/13.md) (hence **had said**). The ULT takes this view, however, for languages where it is hard to express events out of order, the UST reflects the other grammatical possibility and says in [24:13](../24/13.md) that Moses started up the mountain and in [24:15](../24/15.md) that he went the rest of the way up the mountain. Following this, you can view this verse as if Moses paused and gave these final instructions as he was leaving the elders behind, thus keeping a sequential structure. Either approach is permissible by the text, but the approach of the ULT is preferred, if possible.
Alternate translation: [Joshua and me]
**Hur** is a man’s name. See how you translated this name in [Exodus 17:10](../17/10.md).

**Behold** is used to draw attention to important information that Moses is about to tell them. It is frequently omitted. If your language uses a statement to draw attention to important information, you should consider using it here. Alternate translation: [Remember]

This is an idiom that means that someone has a legal dispute or complaint. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [Whoever has a legal claim] or [Anyone with a law case]

bsb_verse_text: and the glory of the LORD settled on Mount Sinai. For six days the cloud covered it, and on the seventh day the LORD called to Moses from within the cloud.
ult_verse_text: And the glory of Yahweh settled on Mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it six days. And on the seventh day he called to Moses from within the cloud.

notes.note: This was the brilliant light of Yahweh’s presence. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the brilliant light showing Yahweh’s presence]
Alternate translation: [6]
If your language does not use ordinal numbers, you can use cardinal numbers here. Alternate translation: [on day number 7]

bsb_verse_text: And the sight of the glory of the LORD was like a consuming fire on the mountaintop in the eyes of the Israelites.
ult_verse_text: And the appearance of the glory of Yahweh was like a devouring fire on the top of the mountain in the eyes of the sons of Israel.

notes.note: This means the glory of Yahweh was very large and seemed to burn brightly, like a fire. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent comparison or express this meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [like a big fire burning]
