Their **eyes** represent seeing, and seeing represents their thoughts or judgment about what they saw. If your readers would not understand what this image means in this context, you could use an equivalent idiom from your culture. Alternatively, you could express the meaning plainly. See how you translated a similar expression in [15:26](../15/26.md). Alternate translation: [to the Israelites]

bsb_verse_text: Moses entered the cloud as he went up on the mountain, and he remained on the mountain forty days and forty nights.
ult_verse_text: And Moses entered the middle of the cloud and went up to the mountain. And Moses was on the mountain 40 days and 40 nights.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [forty days and forty nights]

bsb_verse_text: “Tell the Israelites to bring Me an offering. You are to receive My offering from every man whose heart compels him.
ult_verse_text: “Speak to the sons of Israel, and they shall take a contribution for me. You shall take my contribution from every man whose heart incites him.

notes.note: The beginning of this verse marks the start of a very long direct quote which continues until the end of [30:10](../30/10.md). It may be helpful to your readers to indicate this with an opening first-level quotation mark or with whatever other punctuation or convention your language uses to indicate the beginning of a quotation.

In some languages you may have to make **and they shall take a contribution for me** a direct quote. Note that this will make it a second-level quotation and you will need to mark it with second-level quotation marking if your language uses them. Alternate translation: [Say to the sons of Israel, ‘You shall take a contribution for me.’]
This is an idiom that indicates a person’s desire to give an offering. Many languages will have a similar idiom, though the body part may vary. Alternate translation: [who wants to give one]
The word **you** is plural and refers to Moses and the leaders.

bsb_verse_text: blue, purple, and scarlet yarn; fine linen and goat hair;
ult_verse_text: and blue and purple and worm of scarlet and fine linen and goats’ hair

notes.note: This could mean: (1) “material that is dyed blue, purple, and scarlet,” probably wool yarn, or (2) “blue, purple and scarlet dye” to dye the linen. The original audience would have known what was meant. This material seems to have been used for embroidery later, so “yarn” or “thread” may be the best understanding.
A bright red color for dying cloth was extracted from these worms. Alternate translation: [and bright red]

bsb_verse_text: ram skins dyed red and fine leather; acacia wood;
ult_verse_text: and reddened hides of rams and hides of sea cows and wood of acacias,

notes.note: When animal skins are tanned (processed into usable leather), they become reddish in color. It is not clear whether these hides are dyed red or simply reddened in the tanning process. Alternate translation: [tanned]
The meaning of this word is not known. It may refer to some water mammal that has skin that can be made into a high-quality leather. [Sea cows on Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sirenia)
A small tree with spreading foliage and durable wood. [See on Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shittah_tree)

bsb_verse_text: olive oil for the light; spices for the anointing oil and for the fragrant incense;
ult_verse_text: oil for the light; spices for the oil of anointing and for the incense of fragrance;

notes.note: Here, **spices** are things made from parts of plants that people dry and then grind into a powder to put in oil or food, giving it a particular smell or flavor.

bsb_verse_text: and onyx stones and gemstones to be mounted on the ephod and breastpiece.
ult_verse_text: stones of onyx and precious stones for settings for the ephod and for the breastpiece.

notes.note: An **onyx** is a valuable stone that has layers of white and black, red, or brown. If this stone is unknown to your people, consider translating it by using a word for a familiar stone with a similar pattern, if possible.
Alternate translation: [and valuable gems for] or [and treasured gems for]

bsb_verse_text: You must make the tabernacle and design all its furnishings according to the pattern I show you.
ult_verse_text: according to all that I am about to show you—the pattern of the Dwelling and the pattern of all of its utensils—and thus you shall make it.

notes.note: Here, **you** is singular and refers to Moses.

Here, **utensils** is a general term that you could translate by a broad term that could encompass all of the things used in the Dwelling, as described in this and the several following chapters. Alternate translation: [its implements]
Here, **you** is plural and refers to Moses and the people of Israel. If your language uses different forms of “you” depending on the number of people addressed, use a plural form here.
Since Moses does not construct these items himself, you may consider shifting the instructions to the third person if it would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [they shall make it]

bsb_verse_text: And they are to construct an ark of acacia wood, two and a half cubits long, a cubit and a half wide, and a cubit and a half high.
ult_verse_text: And they shall make a box of wood of acacias—its length: two cubits and a half; and its width: one cubit and a half; and its height: one cubit and a half.

notes.note: These trees, **acacias**, are small trees with spreading foliage and durable wood. See how you translated this in [25:5](../25/05.md). [See on Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shittah_tree)

notes.orig_language_quote: אַמָּתַ֨יִם וָ⁠חֵ֜צִי & וְ⁠אַמָּ֤ה וָ⁠חֵ֨צִי֙ & וְ⁠אַמָּ֥ה וָ⁠חֵ֖צִי
notes.note: If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurements, either in the text or a footnote. A **cubit** is approximately 46cm. For your reference, a more precise conversion to metric is: 115cm … 69cm … 69cm
A **half** means one part out of two equal parts.

bsb_verse_text: Cast four gold rings for it and fasten them to its four feet, two rings on one side and two on the other.
ult_verse_text: And you shall cast four rings of gold for it and put {them} on its four feet: two rings on its one side and two rings on its second side.

notes.note: Casting rings was a process in which gold was melted, poured into a mold that was in the shape of a ring, and then allowed to cool and harden. If this sort of metal-working process is unknown to your people, you may simply describe it, or use a word meaning “make,” as the UST does. The UST approach is preferred, as the creation process is not in focus here, and it would be cumbersome to include the description in the text. You could use a word meaning “make,” and include the description in a footnote if you are including those and your team feels it is important to understand. Alternate translation: [You shall make four rings of gold by melting the gold and pouring it into molds]

bsb_verse_text: And make poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make poles of wood of acacias and overlay them {with} gold.

notes.note: A small tree with spreading foliage and durable wood. See how you translated this in [25:5](../25/05.md). [See on Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shittah_tree)

bsb_verse_text: The poles are to remain in the rings of the ark; they must not be removed.
ult_verse_text: The poles shall be in the rings of the ark; they shall not be removed from it.

notes.orig_language_quote: בְּ⁠טַבְּעֹת֙ הָ⁠אָרֹ֔ן יִהְי֖וּ הַ⁠בַּדִּ֑ים לֹ֥א יָסֻ֖רוּ מִמֶּֽ⁠נּוּ
notes.note: These two phrases mean similar things. Yahweh is saying the same thing in two different ways to emphasize how important this command is. If saying the same thing twice might be confusing for your readers, you can combine the phrases into one. Alternate translation: [The poles belong in the rings of the box; no one is ever to remove them]

notes.orig_language_quote: בְּ⁠טַבְּעֹת֙ הָ⁠אָרֹ֔ן יִהְי֖וּ הַ⁠בַּדִּ֑ים לֹ֥א יָסֻ֖רוּ מִמֶּֽ⁠נּוּ
notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language, as seen in the UST.

bsb_verse_text: And you are to construct a mercy seat of pure gold, two and a half cubits long and a cubit and a half wide.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make an atonement lid of pure gold—its length: two cubits and a half; and its width: a cubit and a half.

notes.note: If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurements, either in the text or a footnote. A **cubit** is approximately 46cm. For your reference, a more precise conversion to the metric system is: 115 centimeters … 69 centimeters … 69 centimeters
A **half** means one part out of two equal parts.

bsb_verse_text: one cherub on one end and one on the other, all made from one piece of gold.
ult_verse_text: And make one cherub from this end and one cherub from this end. You shall make the cherubim from the atonement lid on its two ends.

notes.note: This seems to indicate that the cherubim should be formed out of the same piece of gold as the rest of the lid. It may, however, mean that at the end they should be one piece, so the gold should be heated to melting and the lid and cherubim joined together. Alternate translation: [You shall join the cherubim to the atonement lid on its two ends]

bsb_verse_text: And I will meet with you there above the mercy seat, between the two cherubim that are over the ark of the Testimony; I will speak with you about all that I command you regarding the Israelites.
ult_verse_text: And I will meet with you there and I will speak with you all that I will command you for the sons of Israel from above the atonement lid, from between the two cherubim which are above the Box of the Testimony.

notes.note: Here, **you** is singular and refers to Moses. If you have been using a plural you for Yahweh’s commands which have been to give to others, make sure you use the singular form of “you” here.

bsb_verse_text: You are also to make a table of acacia wood two cubits long, a cubit wide, and a cubit and a half high.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make a table from wood of acacias. Its length: two cubits, and its width: a cubit, and its height: a cubit and a half.

notes.orig_language_quote: אַמָּתַ֤יִם אָרְכּ⁠וֹ֙ וְ⁠אַמָּ֣ה רָחְבּ֔⁠וֹ וְ⁠אַמָּ֥ה וָ⁠חֵ֖צִי קֹמָתֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurements, either in the text or a footnote. A **cubit** is approximately 46 centimeters. Alternate translation: [Its length: 92 centimeters, its width: 46 centimeters and its height: 69 centimeters]
A **half** means one part out of two equal parts.
This verse is almost identical to [25:11](../25/11.md).

bsb_verse_text: And make a rim around it a handbreadth wide and put a gold molding on the rim.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make a rim for it, a handbreadth all around, and you shall make a border of gold around its rim.

notes.note: You can convert this length to a measurement system familiar to your people if that is the style of translation that you are using. A **handbreadth** is a measurement of approximately eight centimeters.
Alternate translation: [for the table]

bsb_verse_text: The rings are to be close to the rim, to serve as holders for the poles used to carry the table.
ult_verse_text: The rings shall be close to the rim to house the poles to carry the table.

notes.note: Here, **to house the poles** means that the rings will hold the poles. Since the rings are where the poles belong for use when carrying the table, the rings are in their **house.** If your language has a similar idiom meaning “place of belonging,” you may use it, or you may translate the idea. Alternate translation: [to be a place for]

bsb_verse_text: Make the poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold, so that the table may be carried with them.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make the poles {out of} wood of acacias and cover them {with} gold, and the table shall be carried with them.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And you shall carry the table with them]

bsb_verse_text: You are also to make the plates and dishes, as well as the pitchers and bowls for pouring drink offerings. Make them out of pure gold.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make its plates and its pans and its pitchers and its bowls with which it will be poured out. You shall make them {from} pure gold.

notes.note: We do not know precisely what these dishes were. It is likely that the **plates** were mostly flat dishes for holding the bread that would be on the table. The **pans** may have been shallow bowls or deep plates for holding incense, or they may have been something more like a ladle or spoon. The **pitchers** probably held wine to be poured into the **bowls** for the drink offerings. You will need to translate using the closest word for each such item in your culture.

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [from which the priests will pour out]

bsb_verse_text: And place the Bread of the Presence on the table before Me at all times.
ult_verse_text: And you shall continually put the bread of faces on the table before my face.

notes.note: Here, **faces** represents the presence of Yahweh. This bread represented the presence of God. Alternate translation: [the bread of the Presence]
Here, **face** represents the presence of Yahweh. Alternate translation: [in front of me]

bsb_verse_text: Then you are to make a lampstand of pure, hammered gold. It shall be made of one piece, including its base and shaft, its cups, and its buds and petals.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make a lampstand of pure gold. The lampstand—its base and its shaft—shall be made of hammered work. Its cups, its buds, and its blossoms shall be from it.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [of beaten gold] See how you translated this in [Exodus 25:18](../25/18.md).
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you shall make]

bsb_verse_text: There are to be three cups shaped like almond blossoms on the first branch, each with buds and petals, three on the next branch, and the same for all six branches that extend from the lampstand.
ult_verse_text: Three cups, shaped like almond blossoms, shall be on the one branch, a bulb, and a blossom. And three cups, shaped like almond blossoms, shall be on the one branch, a bulb, and a blossom—thus for the six branches going out from the lampstand.

notes.note: **Almond blossoms** are white or pink flowers with five petals. (An almond is a kind of nut.) You may want to include a short description as a footnote or in the text (if that is your translation style) the first time this object is encountered. Alternate translation: [shaped like the five-petaled almond flower]

bsb_verse_text: For the six branches that extend from the lampstand, a bud must be under the first pair of branches, a bud under the second pair, and a bud under the third pair.
ult_verse_text: And a bulb will be under two of the branches from it, and a bulb will be under two of the branches from it, and a bulb will be under two of the branches from it—for all six branches extending out from the lampstand.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠כַפְתֹּ֡ר תַּחַת֩ שְׁנֵ֨י הַ⁠קָּנִ֜ים מִמֶּ֗⁠נָּה וְ⁠כַפְתֹּר֙ תַּ֣חַת שְׁנֵ֤י הַ⁠קָּנִים֙ מִמֶּ֔⁠נָּה וְ⁠כַפְתֹּ֕ר תַּחַת־שְׁנֵ֥י הַ⁠קָּנִ֖ים מִמֶּ֑⁠נָּה לְ⁠שֵׁ֨שֶׁת֙ הַ⁠קָּנִ֔ים הַ⁠יֹּצְאִ֖ים מִן־הַ⁠מְּנֹרָֽה
notes.note: Alternate translation: [There must be a leafy base under the first pair of branches—made as one piece with it, and a leafy base under the second pair of branches—also made as one piece with it. In the same way there must be a leafy base under the third pair of branches, made as one piece with it. It must be the same for all six branches extending out from the lampstand.]

bsb_verse_text: The buds and branches are to be all of one piece with the lampstand, hammered out of pure gold.
ult_verse_text: Their bulbs and their branches from it shall all be one piece of hammered work of pure gold.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [of beaten gold] See how you translated this in [Exodus 25:18](../25/18.md).

bsb_verse_text: Make seven lamps and set them up on the lampstand so that they illuminate the area in front of it.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make its seven lamps, and it will hold up its lamps, and it will make light on the side of its face.

notes.note: Here, **face** represents the location of the lampstand. Alternate translation: [so they shine light near it]

bsb_verse_text: The lampstand and all these utensils shall be made from a talent of pure gold.
ult_verse_text: He shall make it, all these items, from a talent of pure gold.

notes.note: If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurements, either in the text or a footnote. A talent weighs about 33 kilograms.

bsb_verse_text: See to it that you make everything according to the pattern shown you on the mountain.
ult_verse_text: See and make by the pattern that you are being shown on the mountain.

notes.note: All the items described in this chapter are included in what Moses is told to **see and make**. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [See and make everything I have described]

Here, **see** relates to observing or overseeing. Essentially, Yahweh is telling Moses to be careful as he observes the pattern on the mountain and as he sees the craftsmen of Israel working on these items, so that they are made correctly. Alternate translation: [Observe carefully and work exactly]
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [I am showing you]

bsb_verse_text: “You are to construct the tabernacle itself with ten curtains of finely spun linen, each with blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and cherubim skillfully worked into them.
ult_verse_text: And the Dwelling you shall make with ten curtains: twisted fine linen and blue and purple and worm of scarlet; cherubim—the work of a skilled craftsman you shall make them.

notes.note: Yahweh is speaking to Moses, so the word **you** is singular. Yahweh probably expected Moses to tell someone else to do the actual work, but Moses would be the one responsible for seeing that the work was done correctly. Alternate translation: [, tell a craftsman to make]

This could mean: (1) “material that is dyed blue, purple, and scarlet,” probably wool yarn, or (2) “blue, purple and scarlet dye” to dye the linen. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Exodus 25:4](../25/04.md).
A bright red color for dying cloth was extracted from these worms. Alternate translation: [and bright red]
This was cloth made from fine linen threads that someone twisted together to make a stronger thread.
a person who is skilled in making beautiful objects by hand

bsb_verse_text: Each curtain shall be twenty-eight cubits long and four cubits wide—all curtains the same size.
ult_verse_text: The length of each curtain shall be 28 cubits and the width of each curtain shall be 4 cubits. All of the curtains shall be one size.

notes.note: If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurements, either in the text or a footnote. A **cubit** is approximately 46 centimeters. For your reference, a more precise conversion to metric is: 12.9 meters … 184 centimeters.

bsb_verse_text: Five of the curtains are to be joined together, and the other five joined as well.
ult_verse_text: Five of the curtains shall be joined each to another and five of the curtains joined each to another.

notes.orig_language_quote: חֲמֵ֣שׁ הַ⁠יְרִיעֹ֗ת תִּֽהְיֶ֨יןָ֙ חֹֽבְרֹ֔ת אִשָּׁ֖ה אֶל־אֲחֹתָ֑⁠הּ וְ⁠חָמֵ֤שׁ יְרִיעֹת֙ חֹֽבְרֹ֔ת אִשָּׁ֖ה אֶל־אֲחֹתָֽ⁠הּ
notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Join five of the curtains each to another, and join five of the curtains each to another.]

bsb_verse_text: Make loops of blue material on the edge of the end curtain in the first set, and do the same for the end curtain in the second set.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make loops of blue on the edge of the first curtain from the edge in the set. And you shall do thus along the edge of the end curtain in the second set.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [blue yarn] or [blue cloth]
If your language does not use ordinal numbers, you can use cardinal numbers here.
Alternate translation: [in one set of five curtains]
Alternate translation: [in the other set of five curtains]

bsb_verse_text: Make fifty loops on one curtain and fifty loops on the end curtain of the second set, so that the loops line up opposite one another.
ult_verse_text: You shall make 50 loops on the first curtain, and you shall make 50 loops on the end of the curtain which is in the second set. The loops should be opposite woman to her sister.

notes.note: This is an idiom meaning “to each other.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [one to the other]

bsb_verse_text: Make fifty gold clasps as well, and join the curtains together with the clasps, so that the tabernacle will be a unit.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make 50 clasps of gold and join the curtains woman to her sister with the clasps, and the Dwelling will be one.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠עָשִׂ֕יתָ חֲמִשִּׁ֖ים קַרְסֵ֣י זָהָ֑ב וְ⁠חִבַּרְתָּ֨ אֶת־הַ⁠יְרִיעֹ֜ת אִשָּׁ֤ה אֶל־אֲחֹתָ⁠הּ֙
notes.note: The clasps fit into the loops ([verses 4](../26/04.md) and [5](../26/05.md)) to hold the curtains together.
This is the same idiom as in the previous verse, meaning together. Alternate translation: [to each other]
Alternate translation: [as though it were one piece]

bsb_verse_text: You are to make curtains of goat hair for the tent over the tabernacle—eleven curtains in all.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make curtains of goats’ hair for a tent over the Dwelling. You shall make 11 of these curtains.

notes.note: This refers to an outer tent over the sacred tent. Alternate translation: [for an outer tent]
Alternate translation: [eleven]

bsb_verse_text: Each of the eleven curtains is to be the same size—thirty cubits long and four cubits wide.
ult_verse_text: The length of each curtain {shall be} 30 cubits, and the width of each curtain {shall be} 4 cubits. The 11 curtains {shall be} the same size.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [thirty … four … eleven]

If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurements, either in the text or a footnote. A **cubit** is approximately 46cm. For your reference, a more precise conversion to metric is: 13.8 meter … 184 centimeters

bsb_verse_text: Join five of the curtains into one set and the other six into another. Then fold the sixth curtain over double at the front of the tent.
ult_verse_text: And you shall join five curtains to each other and six curtains to each other. And you shall double over the sixth curtain at the front of the face of the tent.

notes.note: Here, **face** is probably referring to the entrance of the tent. The opening for the protective tent and the sacred tent would have been coordinated so they were in the same place. Alternate translation: [in front of the entrance of the tent]
As in [26:7](../26/07.md), **the tent** refers to the outer tent over the sacred tent. Alternate translation: [the outer tent]

bsb_verse_text: Make fifty loops along the edge of the end curtain in the first set, and fifty loops along the edge of the corresponding curtain in the second set.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make 50 loops on the edge of the one end curtain in the joined set and 50 loops on the edge of the curtain in the second joined set.

notes.note: See how you translated a very similar text in [Exodus 26:4](../26/04.md).

bsb_verse_text: Make fifty bronze clasps and put them through the loops to join the tent together as a unit.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make 50 clasps of bronze and put the clasps in the loops and join them and the tent will be one.

notes.note: The **clasps** fit into the loops to hold the curtains together. See how you translated this in [Exodus 26:6](../26/06.md).

bsb_verse_text: As for the overlap that remains of the tent curtains, the half curtain that is left over shall hang down over the back of the tabernacle.
ult_verse_text: And the remaining excess curtain of the tent, the half curtain remaining, shall hang over the back of the Dwelling.

notes.note: A **half** means one part out of two equal parts.

bsb_verse_text: And the tent curtains will be a cubit longer on either side, and the excess will hang over the sides of the tabernacle to cover it.
ult_verse_text: And a cubit from this side and a cubit from that side, the excess of the length of the curtains of the tent shall hang over the sides of the Dwelling from this side and from that side, to cover it.

notes.note: If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurements, either in the text or a footnote. A **cubit** is approximately 46 centimeters. For your reference, a more precise conversion to metric is: 46 centimeters

bsb_verse_text: Also make a covering for the tent out of ram skins dyed red, and over that a covering of fine leather.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make a covering for the tent of reddened hides of rams, and a covering of hides of sea-cows above that.

notes.note: The meaning of this word, **sea cows**, is not known. It may refer to a water mammal that has skin that can be made into a high-quality leather. [Sea cows on Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sirenia) See how you translated a similar phrase in [Exodus 25:5](../25/05.md).

When animal skins are tanned (processed into usable leather), they become reddish. It is not clear if these hides are dyed red or simply reddened in the tanning process. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Exodus 25:5](../25/05.md). Alternate translation: [tanned]

bsb_verse_text: You are to construct upright frames of acacia wood for the tabernacle.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make upright frames for the Dwelling from wood of acacias.

notes.note: Here, **frames** refers to open wooden structures made to hold the curtains.
The **acacias** are relatively small trees with spreading foliage and durable wood. See how you translated this in [25:5](../25/05.md). [See on Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shittah_tree)

bsb_verse_text: Each frame is to be ten cubits long and a cubit and a half wide.
ult_verse_text: The length of a frame shall be ten cubits, and the width of one frame shall be a cubit and a half of a cubit.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [10 … 1.5 cubits]

If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurements, either in the text or a footnote. A **cubit** is approximately 46 centimeters. For your reference, a more precise conversion to metric is: 4.6 meters … 69 centimeters.
A **half** means one part out of two equal parts.

bsb_verse_text: Two tenons must be connected to each other for each frame. Make all the frames of the tabernacle in this way.
ult_verse_text: There shall be two tenons in each frame for joining a woman to her sister. Thus you shall make all of the frames of the Dwelling.

notes.note: Here, the term **tenons** means a part of the wood sticking out from the rest of the frame so that it can be put into a hole in another object.
This is an idiom meaning “to each other.” See how you translated this in [26:5](../26/05.md). Alternate translation: [one to the other]

bsb_verse_text: with forty silver bases under the twenty frames—two bases for each frame, one under each tenon.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make 40 bases of silver under the 20 frames: two bases under one frame for its two tenons, and two bases under one frame for its two tenons.

notes.note: The **bases of silver** were silver blocks that had a slot in them to keep the board in place and off the ground.

notes.orig_language_quote: שְׁנֵ֨י אֲדָנִ֜ים תַּֽחַת־הַ⁠קֶּ֤רֶשׁ הָ⁠אֶחָד֙ לִ⁠שְׁתֵּ֣י יְדֹתָ֔י⁠ו וּ⁠שְׁנֵ֧י אֲדָנִ֛ים תַּֽחַת־הַ⁠קֶּ֥רֶשׁ הָ⁠אֶחָ֖ד לִ⁠שְׁתֵּ֥י יְדֹתָֽי⁠ו

bsb_verse_text: You are also to make five crossbars of acacia wood for the frames on one side of the tabernacle,
ult_verse_text: And you shall make crossbars of wood of acacias—five for the frames of the one side of the Dwelling,

notes.note: The **crossbars** are horizontal support beams that give stability to the structure.

bsb_verse_text: Overlay the frames with gold and make gold rings to hold the crossbars. Also overlay the crossbars with gold.
ult_verse_text: And you shall cover the frames with gold. And you shall make their rings of gold, the holders for the crossbars. And you shall cover the bars with gold.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [which will hold the crossbars] or [because they will hold the crossbars]
The **crossbars** are horizontal support beams that give stability to the structure. See how you translated this in [Exodus 26:26](../26/26.md).

bsb_verse_text: So you are to set up the tabernacle according to the pattern shown you on the mountain.
ult_verse_text: And you shall set up the Dwelling according to its plan that you were shown on the mountain.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. See UST.

bsb_verse_text: Make a veil of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and finely spun linen, with cherubim skillfully worked into it.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make a curtain of blue, and purple and worm of scarlet and of twisted fine linen; the work of a skillful workman, he shall make cherubim.

notes.note: See how you translated very similar text in [Exodus 26:1](../26/01.md).

bsb_verse_text: And hang the veil from the clasps and place the ark of the Testimony behind the veil. So the veil will separate the Holy Place from the Most Holy Place.
ult_verse_text: And you shall hang the curtain under the clasps, and you shall bring the Box of the Testimony there inside the curtain. And the curtain shall separate for you between the Holy and the Holy of Holies.

notes.note: The **clasps** fit into the loops to hold the curtains together. See how you translated these in [Exodus 26:6](../26/06.md).

Here, **Holy of Holies** means extremely or uniquely holy. If this form would not express that this place would become uniquely holy in your language you may need to find another way to express this idea. Alternate translation: [the Most Holy Place] or [the Extraordinarily Holy Place]

bsb_verse_text: Put the mercy seat on the ark of the Testimony in the Most Holy Place.
ult_verse_text: And you shall put the atonement lid on the Box of the Testimony in the Holy of Holies.

notes.note: Here, **Holy of Holies** means extremely holy, as in, the holiest of the holy places. If this form would not express that this place would become uniquely holy in your language you may need to find another way to express this idea. See how you translated it in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [in the Most Holy Place] or [in the Extraordinarily Holy Place]

bsb_verse_text: And place the table outside the veil on the north side of the tabernacle, and put the lampstand opposite the table, on the south side.
ult_verse_text: And you shall put the table outside the curtain and the lampstand opposite the table on the south side of the Dwelling. And put the table on the north side.

notes.note: This is the **table** Yahweh told Moses how to make in [25:23–30](../25/23.md) and the **lampstand** he told him how to make in [25:31–39](../25/31.md).

bsb_verse_text: For the entrance to the tent, you are to make a curtain embroidered with blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and finely spun linen.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make a curtain for the entrance of the tent of blue and purple and worm of scarlet and of twisted fine linen, the work of an embroiderer.

notes.note: See how you translated very similar text in [Exodus 26:1](../26/01.md).

This could mean: (1) “yarn that is dyed blue, purple, and scarlet,” probably wool yarn, or (2) “blue, purple, and scarlet dye” to dye the linen. See how you translated this in [Exodus 25:4](../25/04.md).
This was cloth made from fine linen threads that someone twisted together to make a stronger thread.
Alternate translation: [a person who sews decorative designs into cloth] or [a person who embroiders]

bsb_verse_text: Make five posts of acacia wood for the curtain, overlay them with gold hooks, and cast five bronze bases for them.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make five pillars of acacia wood for the curtain, and you shall overlay them with gold, and their hooks {shall be} gold, and you shall cast five bases of bronze for them.

notes.note: See how you translated very similar instructions in [26:32](../26/32.md).

bsb_verse_text: “You are to build an altar of acacia wood. The altar must be square, five cubits long, five cubits wide, and three cubits high.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make the altar of wood of acacias, five cubits long and five cubits wide. The altar shall be square and three cubits high.

notes.orig_language_quote: חָמֵשׁ֩ אַמּ֨וֹת & וְ⁠חָמֵ֧שׁ אַמּ֣וֹת & וְ⁠שָׁלֹ֥שׁ אַמּ֖וֹת
notes.note: If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurements, either in the text or a footnote. A cubit is approximately 46 centimeters. For your reference, a more precise conversion to metric is: 2.3 meters … 2.3 meters … 138 centimeters

bsb_verse_text: Construct for it a grate of bronze mesh, and make a bronze ring at each of the four corners of the mesh.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make a grate for it, a work of a network of bronze. And you shall make four rings of bronze on the network, on its four corners.

notes.note: The **grate** is a frame of crossed metal bars for holding wood when burning.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠עָשִׂ֣יתָ עַל־הָ⁠רֶ֗שֶׁת אַרְבַּע֙ טַבְּעֹ֣ת נְחֹ֔שֶׁת עַ֖ל אַרְבַּ֥ע קְצוֹתָֽי⁠ו
notes.note: You may want to refer back to several other passages regarding making rings for carrying poles when translating this verse. See [25:12](../25/12.md), [25:26](../25/26.md), and [25:27](../25/27.md).

bsb_verse_text: Set the grate beneath the ledge of the altar, so that the mesh comes halfway up the altar.
ult_verse_text: And you shall put it under the ledge of the altar below, and the network shall be up to the middle of the altar.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠נָתַתָּ֣ה אֹתָ֗⁠הּ תַּ֛חַת כַּרְכֹּ֥ב הַ⁠מִּזְבֵּ֖חַ מִ⁠לְּ⁠מָ֑טָּה וְ⁠הָיְתָ֣ה הָ⁠רֶ֔שֶׁת עַ֖ד חֲצִ֥י הַ⁠מִּזְבֵּֽחַ
notes.note: The grate was placed inside the altar. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly.

bsb_verse_text: The poles are to be inserted into the rings so that the poles are on two sides of the altar when it is carried.
ult_verse_text: And its poles shall be put into the rings, and the poles shall be on the two sides of the altar when carrying it.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And you shall put its poles]

bsb_verse_text: Construct the altar with boards so that it is hollow. It is to be made just as you were shown on the mountain.
ult_verse_text: You shall make it hollow, of planks. Just as he showed you on the mountain, so they shall do.

notes.note: Here, **he** refers to Yahweh in the third person. If it would be unnatural in your language for someone to refer to himself in this way, you may need to change it. Alternate translation: [I showed] or [Yahweh showed]

Here, **they** refers to whoever will make all these items. It is an indication that even though Yahweh has been speaking to Moses in the singular throughout, these instructions are meant to be conveyed to Israelite craftsmen. See Chapter 25 Introduction for more information.

bsb_verse_text: You are also to make a courtyard for the tabernacle. On the south side of the courtyard make curtains of finely spun linen, a hundred cubits long on one side,
ult_verse_text: And you shall make the courtyard of the Dwelling. There shall be curtains of fine twisted linen on the south side of the courtyard; one side shall be 100 cubits long,

notes.note: This was cloth made from fine linen threads that someone twisted together to make a stronger thread. See how you translated this in [Exodus 25:4](../25/04.md).

You can convert this length to a measurement system familiar to your people if that is the style of translation that you are using. A cubit is approximately 46 centimeters. For your reference, a more precise conversion to metric is: 46 meters

bsb_verse_text: with twenty posts and twenty bronze bases, and silver hooks and bands on the posts.
ult_verse_text: with its 20 pillars and their 20 bronze bases, the hooks of the pillars and their rings of silver.

notes.note: Here, **bronze** may refer to both the **pillars** and the **bases**, or just to the **bases.** The pillars inside the tent were of wood overlaid with gold; these may be wood overlaid with bronze.

bsb_verse_text: Likewise there are to be curtains on the north side, a hundred cubits long, with twenty posts and twenty bronze bases, and with silver hooks and bands on the posts.
ult_verse_text: And thus for the north side, the length of the curtains: 100 long, and its 20 pillars, 20 bases of bronze, hooks of the pillars, and rings of silver.

notes.note: See how you translated many similar words in [Exodus 27:9–10](../27/09.md).

notes.note: You can convert this length to a measurement system familiar to your people if that is the style of translation that you are using. A cubit is approximately 46 centimeters. For your reference, a more precise conversion to metric is: 23 meters

bsb_verse_text: The east side of the courtyard, toward the sunrise, is to be fifty cubits wide.
ult_verse_text: And the width of the courtyard, on the east side, shall be 50 cubits.

notes.note: You can convert this length to a measurement system familiar to your people if that is the style of translation that you are using. A cubit is approximately 46 centimeters. For your reference, a more precise conversion to metric is: 23 meters

ult_verse_text: The curtains for the side {shall be} fifteen cubits {with} their three pillars and their three bases.

bsb_verse_text: The gate of the courtyard shall be twenty cubits long, with a curtain embroidered with blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and finely spun linen. It shall have four posts and four bases.
ult_verse_text: And the gate of the courtyard shall be a curtain 20 cubits wide of blue and purple and worm of scarlet and of twisted fine linen—the work of an embroiderer—with its four pillars and its four bases.

notes.orig_language_quote: תְּכֵ֨לֶת וְ⁠אַרְגָּמָ֜ן וְ⁠תוֹלַ֧עַת שָׁנִ֛י וְ⁠שֵׁ֥שׁ מָשְׁזָ֖ר

ult_verse_text: All the pillars of the courtyard shall be banded around with silver, and their silver hooks, and their bases of bronze.

notes.orig_language_quote: מֵאָ֨ה בָֽ⁠אַמָּ֜ה & חֲמִשִּׁ֣ים בַּ⁠חֲמִשִּׁ֗ים & חָמֵ֥שׁ אַמּ֖וֹת
notes.note: If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurements, either in the text or a footnote. A cubit is approximately 46 centimeters. For your reference, a more precise conversion to metric is: 46 meters … 23 meters … 2.3 meters.
