bsb_verse_text: All the utensils of the tabernacle for every use, including all its tent pegs and the tent pegs of the courtyard, shall be made of bronze.
ult_verse_text: All of the equipment of the Dwelling for all of its service, and all of its tent pegs and all of the pegs of the courtyard shall be bronze.

notes.note: The **tent pegs** are strong, sharp pieces of metal driven into the ground and used to secure the corners of a tent to the ground or to secure ropes in order to create tension to stabilize something standing upright.

bsb_verse_text: In the Tent of Meeting, outside the veil that is in front of the Testimony, Aaron and his sons are to tend the lamps before the LORD from evening until morning. This is to be a permanent statute for the Israelites for the generations to come.
ult_verse_text: In the tent of meeting, outside the curtain inside of which is the testimony, Aaron and his sons shall arrange it before the face of Yahweh, from evening to morning. This is an eternal statute throughout the generations of the sons of Israel.

notes.note: The **testimony** refers to the chest that contains the sacred slabs of stone on which Yahweh had written his commandments. If it would be more clear to your readers you may include a reference to the chest. Alternate translation: [is the Box of the Testimony]
Here, **it** refers to the lamp mentioned in the previous verse and **arrange** means to set it up for burning, and light it. Alternate translation: [shall set up the lampstand and light it]
Here, **face** represents the presence of Yahweh. Alternate translation: [in front of me]

notes.orig_language_quote: חֻקַּ֤ת עוֹלָם֙ לְ⁠דֹ֣רֹתָ֔⁠ם מֵ⁠אֵ֖ת בְּנֵ֥י יִשְׂרָאֵֽל
notes.note: See how you translated a similar statement in [12:14](../12/14.md)

bsb_verse_text: “Next, have your brother Aaron brought to you from among the Israelites, along with his sons Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar, to serve Me as priests.
ult_verse_text: And you, bring Aaron your brother, and his sons with him near to you from among the sons of Israel to be priests for me—Aaron and Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar, the sons of Aaron!

notes.note: Here, **you** refers to Moses; in this case, it is used to highlight that he is the person who must do the next thing.
Aaron is older than Moses. If your language uses a different term for the sibling relationship based on gender and age order, choose the appropriate one.
These are men’s names.

bsb_verse_text: Make holy garments for your brother Aaron, to give him glory and splendor.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make for Aaron your brother clothes of holiness for glory and for splendor.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **holiness**, you can express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [holy clothes]

bsb_verse_text: You are to instruct all the skilled craftsmen, whom I have filled with a spirit of wisdom, to make garments for Aaron’s consecration, so that he may serve Me as priest.
ult_verse_text: And you, you shall speak to all of the wise of heart, whom I have filled with the spirit of wisdom, and they shall make the clothes of Aaron to set him apart to be a priest for me.

notes.note: Here, **you** refers to Moses; in this case, it is used to highlight that he is the person who must do the next thing.

There is a little bit of parallelism here. Yahweh is clarifying who causes someone to be **wise of heart**. You could translate this in a more causative way if that would make more sense. Alternate translation: [to anyone whom I have filled with the spirit of wisdom, making them wise of heart]

Here, **heart** and **spirit** are both referring to things innately possessed by a person that is, traits of a person. **Wisdom** refers to skill or talent with crafting in this case. Together **wise of heart** and **filled with the spirit of wisdom** both essentially mean “a talented craftsman.” If it would be more clear to your readers, you may consider making some of this more explicit. Alternate translation: [to every talented craftsman, those whom I have made skilled in their work]

bsb_verse_text: These are the garments that they shall make: a breastpiece, an ephod, a robe, a woven tunic, a turban, and a sash. They are to make these holy garments for your brother Aaron and his sons, so that they may serve Me as priests.
ult_verse_text: And these are the clothes that they shall make: a breastpiece and an ephod and a robe and a tunic of woven work, a turban and a sash. And they shall make clothes of holiness for your brother Aaron and for his sons to be priests for me.

notes.note: We do not know what word translated **of woven work** means, as it only occurs here and in [28:39](../28/39.md) as a verb. Alternate translation: [and a checkered tunic] or [an embroidered garment]
This is a head covering made from cloth wrapped around the head several times. You may translate it using a word commonly used for a similar item in your culture.
The **sash** is a piece of cloth that people wear around their waist or across their chest. You may translate it with a word commonly used for a similar item in your culture.
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **holiness**, you can express the same idea in another way. See how you translated this in [28:2](../28/02.md).

bsb_verse_text: They shall use gold, along with blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and fine linen.
ult_verse_text: And they shall take gold and blue and purple and worm of scarlet and fine linen.

notes.note: This could mean: (1) “material that is dyed blue, purple, and scarlet,” probably wool yarn, or (2) “blue, purple and scarlet dye” to dye the linen. The original audience would have known what was meant. This material seems to have been used for embroidery later, so “yarn” or “thread” may be the best understanding. See how you translated this in [25:4](../25/04.md)
A bright red color for dying cloth was extracted from these worms. Alternate translation: [and bright red]

bsb_verse_text: They are to make the ephod of finely spun linen embroidered with gold, and with blue, purple, and scarlet yarn.
ult_verse_text: And they shall make the ephod from gold, blue, and purple, worm of scarlet, and twisted fine linen—the work of a skillful craftsman.

notes.note: This was cloth made from fine linen threads that someone twisted together to make a stronger thread. See how you translated this in [Exodus 26:36](../26/36.md). Alternate translation: [fine twined linen]
The description **skillful craftsman** refers to a person who can make beautiful objects by hand.

bsb_verse_text: It shall have two shoulder pieces attached at two of its corners, so it can be fastened.
ult_verse_text: It shall have two shoulder pieces joining to its two ends; so it shall be joined.

notes.orig_language_quote: שְׁתֵּ֧י כְתֵפֹ֣ת חֹֽבְרֹ֗ת יִֽהְיֶה־לּ֛⁠וֹ אֶל־שְׁנֵ֥י קְצוֹתָ֖י⁠ו וְ⁠חֻבָּֽר
notes.note: This likely meant creating some sort of fastening up by the shoulders to attach the front of the ephod to its back. Alternate translation: [They shall make it so that the front and back attach to each other at the shoulders]
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [join it together that way]

bsb_verse_text: And the skillfully woven waistband of the ephod must be of one piece, of the same workmanship—with gold, with blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and with finely spun linen.
ult_verse_text: And the skillfully-crafted sash of the ephod which is on it shall be of like workmanship, from it: of gold, blue and purple and worm of scarlet and fine twined linen.

notes.note: This is saying that the sash should be attached to the ephod, perhaps cut from the same material used to make the rest of the ephod.

bsb_verse_text: Take two onyx stones and engrave on them the names of the sons of Israel:
ult_verse_text: And you shall take two stones of onyx and you shall engrave on them the names of the sons of Israel,

notes.note: These **stones of onyx** are valuable stones that have layers of white and black, red, or brown. See how you translated this in [Exodus 25:7](../25/07.md).
Alternate translation: [2]

bsb_verse_text: six of their names on one stone and the remaining six on the other, in the order of their birth.
ult_verse_text: six of their names on one stone and the six remaining names on the second stone, according to their genealogies.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [6 of … the 6]
Alternate translation: [according to their birth order]

bsb_verse_text: Engrave the names of the sons of Israel on the two stones the way a gem cutter engraves a seal. Then mount the stones in gold filigree settings.
ult_verse_text: You shall engrave the two stones with the names of the sons of Israel—the work of a craftsman of stone, the engravings of a signet.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [in the same way a person engraves on a seal]
A **craftsman of stone** is a person who cuts designs into stones. Alternate translation: [a detailed stone cutter]
This is an engraved stone often set into a ring and used to stamp a design into a wax seal to authenticate an official document.
These are pieces of metal that hold the stones onto the ephod.

bsb_verse_text: Fasten both stones on the shoulder pieces of the ephod as memorial stones for the sons of Israel. Aaron is to bear their names on his two shoulders as a memorial before the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And you shall put the two stones on the shoulder pieces of the ephod as stones of reminder for the sons of Israel. And Aaron shall carry their names before the face of Yahweh on his two shoulders for a reminder.

notes.note: The text does not specify if Yahweh or Aaron or someone else is the one being reminded by the stones. It also does not specify exactly what the reminder is of. Try to maintain this ambiguity if possible in your translation.
Here, **face** represents the presence of Yahweh. Alternate translation: [in the presence of]

bsb_verse_text: Fashion gold filigree settings
ult_verse_text: And you shall make ornamental settings of gold

notes.note: The **ornamental settings** are pieces of precious metal that surround the sides of hold each stone to hold it onto the ephod. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:11](../28/11.md).

bsb_verse_text: and two chains of pure gold, made of braided cord work; and attach these chains to the settings.
ult_verse_text: and two twisted chains of pure gold: you shall make them as a work of rope, and you shall attach the chains of the rope to the ornamental settings.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠שְׁתֵּ֤י שַׁרְשְׁרֹת֙ זָהָ֣ב טָה֔וֹר מִגְבָּלֹ֛ת תַּעֲשֶׂ֥ה אֹתָ֖⁠ם מַעֲשֵׂ֣ה עֲבֹ֑ת
notes.note: Alternate translation: [and you shall make two chains of pure gold that are braided like cords]

bsb_verse_text: You are also to make a breastpiece of judgment with the same workmanship as the ephod. Construct it with gold, with blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and with finely spun linen.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make a breastpiece of judgment—the work of a skillful craftsman—you shall make it like the work of the ephod; you shall make it from gold, blue, and purple, and worm of scarlet, and twisted fine linen.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [a skillful workman will make it like the ephod]

bsb_verse_text: It must be square when folded over double, a span long and a span wide.
ult_verse_text: It shall be square, folded double; its length: a span; and its width: a span.

notes.note: You can convert this length to a measurement system familiar to your people if that is the style of translation that you are using. A span is approximately 23 centimeters.
Alternate translation: [Fold it in half so it will be square]

bsb_verse_text: And mount on it a setting of gemstones, four rows of stones: In the first row there shall be a ruby, a topaz, and an emerald;
ult_verse_text: And you shall set in it settings of precious stone—four stone rows. The first row shall be a row with a ruby, a topaz, and a garnet.

notes.note: These are precious stones.
Twelve kinds of stones are listed in the next four verses. Scholars are not sure which kinds of stones the Hebrew words refer to. Some translations list different stones.

bsb_verse_text: in the second row a turquoise, a sapphire, and a diamond;
ult_verse_text: And the second row: an emerald, a sapphire, and a diamond.

notes.note: If your language does not use ordinal numbers, you can use cardinal numbers here. Alternate translation: [And row 2:]
These are precious stones.
This is a gemstone that is blue in color. See how you translated this in [Exodus 24:10](../24/10.md).

bsb_verse_text: in the third row a jacinth, an agate, and an amethyst;
ult_verse_text: And the third row: a jacinth, an agate, and an amethyst.

notes.note: If your language does not use ordinal numbers, you can use cardinal numbers here. Alternate translation: [And row 3:]
These are precious stones

bsb_verse_text: and in the fourth row a beryl, an onyx, and a jasper. Mount these stones in gold filigree settings.
ult_verse_text: And the fourth row: a beryl, and an onyx, and a jasper. They shall be set in gold—in their ornamental settings.

notes.note: If your language does not use ordinal numbers, you can use cardinal numbers here. Alternate translation: [And row 4:]
These are precious stones.
An **onyx** is a valuable stone that has layers of white and black, red, or brown. See how you translated these in [Exodus 25:7](../25/07.md).
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [You shall set them in gold]

bsb_verse_text: The twelve stones are to correspond to the names of the sons of Israel, each engraved like a seal with the name of one of the twelve tribes.
ult_verse_text: And the precious stones shall be according to the names of the sons of Israel—according to their 12 names. Each shall be like the engraving of a signet according to its name—for the 12 tribes.

notes.note: This is an engraved stone often set into a ring and used to stamp a design into a wax seal to authenticate an official document. Here the stone is mounted on a ring. See how you translated “signet” in [Exodus 28:11](../28/11.md).

bsb_verse_text: For the breastpiece, make braided chains like cords of pure gold.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make twisted chains on the breastpiece, as a work of rope—pure gold.

notes.orig_language_quote: שַֽׁרְשֹׁ֥ת גַּבְלֻ֖ת מַעֲשֵׂ֣ה עֲבֹ֑ת זָהָ֖ב טָהֽוֹר
notes.note: See how you translated similar phrases in [Exodus 28:14](../28/14.md). Alternate translation (should replace **twisted chains**): [chains that are made of pure gold and are braided like cords]

bsb_verse_text: and fasten the other ends of the two chains to the two filigree settings, attaching them to the shoulder pieces of the ephod at the front.
ult_verse_text: And you shall attach two of the ends of the two chains to the two ornamental settings, and you shall attach those to the shoulder pieces of the ephod at the front of its face.

notes.note: Here, **face** simply refers to the object (the ephod). Alternate translation: [on its front side]
These are two settings that enclose the stones. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly.

bsb_verse_text: Make two additional gold rings and attach them to the bottom of the two shoulder pieces of the ephod, on its front, near its seam just above its woven waistband.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make two rings of gold, and you shall put them on the two shoulder-pieces of the ephod on the bottom of the front of its face, close to its joining above the skillfully crafted waistband of the ephod.

notes.note: Here, **face** simply refers to the object (the ephod). Alternate translation: [on its front side]
The **waistband** was a cloth belt made from narrow linen threads that someone twisted together to make a stronger thread. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:8](../28/08.md).

bsb_verse_text: The rings of the breastpiece shall be tied to the rings of the ephod with a cord of blue yarn, so that the breastpiece is above the waistband of the ephod and does not swing out from the ephod.
ult_verse_text: And they shall tie the breastpiece by its rings to the rings of the ephod with a cord of blue to be on the finely crafted waistband of the ephod, so the breastpiece shall not become detached from on the ephod.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [so that the breastpiece shall stay attached to]
If this double negative would be misunderstood in your language, you could translate it as a positive statement. Alternate translation: [so that the breastpiece shall stay attached to]

bsb_verse_text: Whenever Aaron enters the Holy Place, he shall bear the names of the sons of Israel over his heart on the breastpiece of judgment, as a continual reminder before the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And Aaron shall bear the names of the sons of Israel in the breastpiece of judgment over his heart when he goes into the Holy Place as a reminder before the face of Yahweh continually.

notes.note: This refers to the names of the tribes engraved on the twelve stones the breastplate as described in [Exodus 28:17–21](../28/17.md).
Alternate translation: [over Aaron’s heart] or [on his chest]

bsb_verse_text: And place the Urim and Thummim in the breastpiece of judgment, so that they will also be over Aaron’s heart whenever he comes before the LORD. Aaron will continually carry the judgment of the sons of Israel over his heart before the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And you shall put the Urim and the Thummim in the breastpiece of judgment, and they shall be over the heart of Aaron when he goes in before the face of Yahweh. And Aaron shall bear the judgment of the sons of Israel over his heart before the face of Yahweh continually.

notes.note: It is not clear what **the Urim and the Thummim** are. They were objects, possibly stones, that the priest used to somehow determine the will of God. Because of this, it is basically impossible to translate. In your translation, you can spell it the way it sounds in your language.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠נָשָׂ֣א אַ֠הֲרֹן אֶת־מִשְׁפַּ֨ט בְּנֵי־יִשְׂרָאֵ֧ל עַל־לִבּ֛⁠וֹ לִ⁠פְנֵ֥י יְהוָ֖ה תָּמִֽיד
notes.note: This phrase appears to refer to the Urim and Thummim and explain their purpose. Alternate translation: [And Aaron shall bear the decisions for the sons of Israel over his heart before Yahweh continually]
Here, **face** represents the presence of Yahweh. Alternate translation: [before Yahweh … before Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: with an opening at its top in the center. Around the opening shall be a woven collar with an opening like that of a garment, so that it will not tear.
ult_verse_text: And there shall be an opening for his head in the middle of it. There shall be an edge for its opening all around, so it can not tear—the work of a weaver, it shall be like an opening of a garment.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [made by a weaver]
Alternate translation: [a person who weaves] or [a person who creates cloth using thread, yarns and wool]
We do not know what this term means, but the implication seems to be that the collar should be made strong.
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language, as modeled in the UST.

bsb_verse_text: Make pomegranates of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn all the way around the lower hem, with gold bells between them,
ult_verse_text: And on its bottom hem you shall make pomegranates of blue, purple, and worm of scarlet all around on its hem with bells of gold between them all around:

notes.note: This could mean: (1) “material that is dyed blue, purple, and scarlet,” probably wool yarn, or (2) “blue, purple and scarlet dye” to dye the linen. The original audience would have known what was meant. This material seems to have been used for embroidery later, so “yarn” or “thread” may be the best understanding. See how you translated this in [25:4](../25/04.md)

bsb_verse_text: alternating the gold bells and pomegranates around the lower hem of the robe.
ult_verse_text: a bell of gold and a pomegranate, a bell of gold and a pomegranate all around the hem of the robe.

notes.orig_language_quote: פַּעֲמֹ֤ן זָהָב֙ וְ⁠רִמּ֔וֹן פַּֽעֲמֹ֥ן זָהָ֖ב וְ⁠רִמּ֑וֹן
notes.note: This phrase is repeated to show the pattern of the design on the robe. Alternate translation: [alternate pomegranates and golden bells]

bsb_verse_text: Aaron must wear the robe whenever he ministers, and its sound will be heard when he enters or exits the sanctuary before the LORD, so that he will not die.
ult_verse_text: And it shall be on Aaron while serving, and its sound shall be heard at his going into the Holy Place before the face of Yahweh and at his leaving. And he shall not die.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [so that the bells make a sound]
Here, **face** represents the presence of Yahweh. Alternate translation: [before Yahweh]
Here, Yahweh refers to himself in the third person. If this is confusing in your language, you may use the first person. Alternate translation: [me]

The probable implication is that he would die because he did not obey Yahweh. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [As a result, he will not die because of disobeying my instructions]

bsb_verse_text: You are to make a plate of pure gold and engrave on it as on a seal: HOLY TO THE LORD.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make a rosette of pure gold and engrave on it, like the engraving on a signet, ‘Holy to Yahweh.’

notes.note: We do not know exactly what this was. It was probably a thin piece of gold smaller than the palm of someone’s hand.
See how you translated similar words in [Exodus 28:11](../28/11.md) Alternate translation: [write on it in the same way a person engraves on a seal.]

bsb_verse_text: Fasten to it a blue cord to mount it on the turban; it shall be on the front of the turban.
ult_verse_text: And you shall attach it by a cord of blue, and it shall be on the turban. It shall be toward the front of the face of the turban.

notes.note: This was a head covering made from cloth wrapped around the head several times. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:4](../28/04.md).
Here, **face** means the front. Alternate translation: [to the front of the turban]

bsb_verse_text: And it will be worn on Aaron’s forehead, so that he may bear the iniquity of the holy things that the sons of Israel consecrate with regard to all their holy gifts. It shall always be on his forehead, so that they may be acceptable before the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And it shall be on the forehead of Aaron, and Aaron shall bear the iniquity of the holy things which the sons of Israel shall cause to be holy, for all of the gifts of their holy things, and it shall be on his forehead continually for their acceptance before the face of Yahweh.

notes.note: Here, **iniquity** is pictured as something that can be carried or worn like the turban. It also seems to picture handing off the iniquity from the people to Aaron. Also here, **iniquity** actually seems to refer to the punishment for anything that might be wrong regarding the things the Israelites offer Yahweh. You may need to use a different word than **bear** to convey the transfer of responsibility for wrongs from the people to Aaron. If your readers would not understand what this image means in this context, you could use an equivalent metaphor from your culture. Alternatively, you could express the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and Aaron shall be responsible for any wrong related to the holy things]
Here, **face** represents the presence of Yahweh. Alternate translation: [before Yahweh]
Here, Yahweh refers to himself in the third person. If this is confusing in your language, you may use the first person. Alternate translation: [me]

bsb_verse_text: You are to weave the tunic with fine linen, make the turban of fine linen, and fashion an embroidered sash.
ult_verse_text: And you shall weave the tunic with fine linen, and you shall make a turban of fine linen. And you shall make a sash, the work of an embroiderer.

notes.note: This was a head covering made from cloth wrapped around the head several times. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:4](../28/04.md).
A **sash** is a decorative piece of cloth that a person wears around his waist or across his chest. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:4](../28/04.md).
An embroiderer is a person who sews decorative designs onto cloth. See how you translated this in [Exodus 26:36](../26/36.md).

bsb_verse_text: Make tunics, sashes, and headbands for Aaron’s sons, to give them glory and splendor.
ult_verse_text: And for the sons of Aaron you shall make tunics, and you shall make sashes for them, and you shall make headbands for them for glory and for splendor.

notes.note: The **sashes** are decorative pieces of cloth that people wear around the waist or across the chest. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:4](../28/04.md).
A headband is a decorative, narrow strip of cloth that is worn around the head above the eyes. This seems to be similar to, but perhaps smaller than the turban worn by the high priest.

bsb_verse_text: After you put these garments on your brother Aaron and his sons, anoint them, ordain them, and consecrate them so that they may serve Me as priests.
ult_verse_text: And you shall clothe them, your brother Aaron and his sons with him. And you shall anoint them, and you shall fill their hand, and you shall set them apart to be priests to me.

notes.note: Aaron is older than Moses. If your language uses a different term for the sibling relationship based on gender and age order, choose the appropriate one.

This seems to be an idiom for giving authority to someone. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [and you shall ordain them]

bsb_verse_text: Make linen undergarments to cover their bare flesh, extending from waist to thigh.
ult_verse_text: And make for them undergarments of linen to cover the flesh of nakedness—they shall be from the waist to the thighs.

notes.note: These are articles of clothing worn under the outer clothes, next to the skin.

This refers to the male genitalia. This is a polite way of referring to something unpleasant. If this would be misunderstood in your language, use a different polite way of referring to this or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [their private parts]

bsb_verse_text: “Now this is what you are to do to consecrate Aaron and his sons to serve Me as priests: Take a young bull and two rams without blemish,
ult_verse_text: And this {is} the thing that you shall do to them to set them apart to be priests to me. Take one bull, a son of the herd, and two unblemished rams

notes.note: A new scene begins here. There is a change in topic from instructions for making garments for priests to consecrating priests. This may need to be marked in a certain way in your language.
Here, **you** refers to Moses.
Here, **they** refers to Aaron and his sons. Alternate translation: [to Aaron and his sons]
Here, **me** refers to Yahweh.
This is an idiom meaning young. If you do not have a similar idiom you may translate the meaning. Alternate translation: [a young one]

bsb_verse_text: along with unleavened bread, unleavened cakes mixed with oil, and unleavened wafers anointed with oil. Make them out of fine wheat flour,
ult_verse_text: and unleavened bread and unleavened cakes mixed with oil and unleavened wafers rubbed with oil. Make them with fine flour of wheat.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. You may need to shorten the sentences and make the alternate translation content separate sentences or mark it off with special punctuation. Alternate translation: [(mix them with oil) … (rub them with oil)]
These may have been rubbed with oil before or after baking.

These are different kinds of food made from flour. While all the breads were somewhat flat because they were unleavened, the **cakes** were a bread enriched with oil, and the **wafers** were especially thin.

bsb_verse_text: put them in a basket, and present them in the basket, along with the bull and the two rams.
ult_verse_text: And you shall put them into one basket, and you shall bring them near in the basket, and the bull and the two rams.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [the bread, cakes, and wafers]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הִקְרַבְתָּ֥ אֹתָ֖⁠ם בַּ⁠סָּ֑ל וְ⁠אֶ֨ת־הַ⁠פָּ֔ר וְ⁠אֵ֖ת שְׁנֵ֥י הָ⁠אֵילִֽם
notes.note: Here, **in the basket** is almost parenthetical. You may need to restructure the sentence or use punctuation to make it clear that **the bull and the two rams** are connected to **bring**, and not to **in the basket.** Alternate translation: [and you shall bring them near (in the basket) along with the bull and the two rams]

bsb_verse_text: Then present Aaron and his sons at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting and wash them with water.
ult_verse_text: And you shall bring Aaron and his sons near to the entrance of the tent of meeting. And you shall wash them with water.

notes.note: The **tent of meeting** is another name for the Dwelling. See how you translated this in [Exodus 27:21](../27/21.md).

bsb_verse_text: Take the garments and clothe Aaron with the tunic, the robe of the ephod, the ephod itself, and the breastplate. Fasten the ephod on him with its woven waistband.
ult_verse_text: And you shall take the garments, and you shall clothe Aaron with the tunic and the robe of the ephod and the ephod and the breastpiece, and you shall fasten the ephod to him with the finely woven waistband of the ephod.

notes.note: This was a cloth belt made from narrow linen threads that someone twisted together to make a stronger thread. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:8](../28/08.md).

bsb_verse_text: Put the turban on his head and attach the holy diadem to the turban.
ult_verse_text: And you shall set the turban on his head and put the crown of holiness on the turban.

notes.note: This was a head covering made from cloth wrapped around the head several times. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:4](../28/04.md).

This **crown** is described in [Exodus 28:36](../28/36.md) as being engraved with the words “Holy to Yahweh” and made of pure gold. There it is referred to by a different Hebrew word, which is translated as “rosette.”
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **holiness**, you can express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the holy crown]

bsb_verse_text: Then take the anointing oil and anoint him by pouring it on his head.
ult_verse_text: And you shall take the oil of anointing and pour it on his head and anoint him.

notes.note: See how you translated **oil of anointing** in [25:6](../25/06.md).

bsb_verse_text: Present his sons as well and clothe them with tunics.
ult_verse_text: And you shall bring his sons and clothe them with tunics.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [Aaron’s sons]

bsb_verse_text: Wrap the sashes around Aaron and his sons and tie headbands on them. The priesthood shall be theirs by a permanent statute. In this way you are to ordain Aaron and his sons.
ult_verse_text: And you shall wrap them—Aaron and his sons—with the sash and bind headbands to them.

notes.note: A **sash** is a decorative piece of cloth that people wear around their waist or across their chest. See how you translated this word in [Exodus 28:4](../28/04.md).
A headband is a narrow, decorative strip of cloth that is worn around the head above the eyes. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:40](../28/40.md).
Here, **the priesthood** means the official office of priest. Alternate translation: [the duty of being priests]

The duty of being priests will also belong to the descendants of Aaron’s sons. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [And the priesthood will belong to them and their descendants]
Alternate translation: [a law that will not end.] See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:43](../28/43.md).

The phrase, **fill the hand**, seems to be an idiom for giving authority to someone. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:41](../28/41.md). Alternate translation: [And you shall ordain Aaron and his sons]

The phrase, **fill the hand** may be (1) a summary and reminder statement of the whole ordination process, (2) referring to the previous description, meaning that the priests have been ordained, or (3) referring to the following description, meaning that the priests are about to be ordained. It would probably be best to translate this in the way a mid-text summary reminder phrase would be spoken in your language, avoiding any indication that it refers only to the previous or following text.

bsb_verse_text: You are to present the bull at the front of the Tent of Meeting, and Aaron and his sons are to lay their hands on its head.
ult_verse_text: And you shall bring the bull to the face of the tent of meeting, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on the head of the bull.

notes.note: The purpose of the sacrifice explained here through [verse 14](../29/14.md) is to purify or cleanse the altar. This is made more clear in [29:36–37](../29/36.md).
Here, **face** refers to the front of the tent. See the UST.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠סָמַ֨ךְ אַהֲרֹ֧ן וּ⁠בָנָ֛י⁠ו אֶת־יְדֵי⁠הֶ֖ם עַל־רֹ֥אשׁ הַ⁠פָּֽר
notes.note: The slaughter of the bull in the next verse occurs while the priests continue to have their hands on the bull’s head. Take care to arrange the phrases and to use words or forms that indicate that the two events happened at the same time.

bsb_verse_text: Take some of the blood of the bull and put it on the horns of the altar with your finger; then pour out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar.
ult_verse_text: And you shall take from the blood of the bull and put it on the horns of the altar with your finger, and you shall pour out all of the blood on the base of the altar.

notes.note: These were projections that looked like ox horns attached to the four corners of the altar. See how you translated this in [Exodus 27:2](../27/02.md).
Alternate translation: [the remaining blood]

bsb_verse_text: Take all the fat that covers the entrails and the lobe of the liver, and both kidneys with the fat on them, and burn them on the altar.
ult_verse_text: And you shall take all of the fat covering the entrails and the lobe above the liver and the two kidneys and the fat that is on them, and cause them to become smoke on the altar.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [and burn them to make smoke]
The **liver** and **kidneys** are organs in the body.

bsb_verse_text: But burn the flesh of the bull and its hide and dung outside the camp; it is a sin offering.
ult_verse_text: But you shall burn the flesh of the bull and its skin and its dung in the fire outside of the camp. It is a purification offering.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [But as for the remaining parts of the bull, including the flesh and dung, you shall burn it]
Alternate translation: [outside the borders of where the Israelites are camped]

bsb_verse_text: Take one of the rams, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on its head.
ult_verse_text: And you shall take one ram, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on the head of the ram,

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠סָ֨מְכ֜וּ אַהֲרֹ֧ן וּ⁠בָנָ֛י⁠ו אֶת־יְדֵי⁠הֶ֖ם עַל־רֹ֥אשׁ הָ⁠אָֽיִל
notes.note: The slaughter of the ram in the next verse occurs while they continue to have their hands on the ram’s head. Take care to arrange the phrases and to use words or forms that indicate that the two events happened at the same time.

bsb_verse_text: Cut the ram into pieces, wash the entrails and legs, and place them with its head and other pieces.
ult_verse_text: And you shall cut the ram into pieces and wash its entrails and its legs and put them on its pieces and on its head,

notes.note: Alternate translation: [the organs] See how you translated this in [Exodus 29:13](../29/13.md).

bsb_verse_text: Then burn the entire ram on the altar; it is a burnt offering to the LORD, a pleasing aroma, a food offering to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: and cause all of the ram to become smoke on the altar. It is a burnt offering to Yahweh. It is a scent of appeasement, a fire offering to Yahweh.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [and burn all of the ram to make smoke]

notes.orig_language_quote: עֹלָ֥ה ה֖וּא לַֽ⁠יהוָ֑ה רֵ֣יחַ נִיח֔וֹחַ אִשֶּׁ֥ה לַ⁠יהוָ֖ה הֽוּא
notes.note: These phrases are in parallel, with the second expanding and clarifying the first. In some languages, you may need to use a different structure to expand and clarify the **burnt offering**. Alternate translation: [It is a pleasant smelling burnt offering made by fire to Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: Take the second ram, and Aaron and his sons are to lay their hands on its head.
ult_verse_text: And you shall take the second ram, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on the head of the ram,

notes.note: Except for **the second,** this verse is identical to [29:15](../29/15.md).

bsb_verse_text: Slaughter the ram, take some of its blood, and put it on the right earlobes of Aaron and his sons, on the thumbs of their right hands, and on the big toes of their right feet. Splatter the remaining blood on all sides of the altar.
ult_verse_text: and you shall slaughter the ram and take some of its blood. And you shall put it on the tip of the right ear of Aaron and on the tip of the right ear of his sons and on the thumb of their right hand and on the great toe of their right foot. And you shall sprinkle the blood all around on the altar.

notes.note: They killed the ram by cutting its throat. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [and kill the ram by cutting its throat]

bsb_verse_text: And take some of the blood on the altar and some of the anointing oil and sprinkle it on Aaron and his garments, as well as on his sons and their garments. Then he and his garments will be consecrated, as well as his sons and their garments.
ult_verse_text: And you shall take some of the blood that is on the altar and some of the oil of anointing and sprinkle it on Aaron and on his garments and on his sons and on the garments of his sons along with him. And he will be set apart and his garments and his sons and the garments of his sons along with him.

notes.note: Moses would mix the blood and oil. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [And you shall take some of the blood that is on the altar and mix it with some of the oil of anointing and sprinkle it]

bsb_verse_text: Take the fat from the ram, the fat tail, the fat covering the entrails, the lobe of the liver, both kidneys with the fat on them, and the right thigh (since this is a ram for ordination),
ult_verse_text: And you shall take the fat from the ram and the fat tail and the fat covering the entrails and the lobe of the liver and the two kidneys and the fat that is on them and the right thigh—for this is a ram of consecration—

notes.note: The **entrails, liver**, and **kidneys** refer to organs inside the body. See how you translated this in [Exodus 29:13](../29/13.md).

bsb_verse_text: along with one loaf of bread, one cake of bread made with oil, and one wafer from the basket of unleavened bread that is before the LORD.
ult_verse_text: and one round loaf of bread, and one cake of bread of oil, and one wafer from the basket of unleavened bread that is before the face of Yahweh.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠כִכַּ֨ר לֶ֜חֶם אַחַ֗ת וַֽ⁠חַלַּ֨ת לֶ֥חֶם שֶׁ֛מֶן אַחַ֖ת וְ⁠רָקִ֣יק אֶחָ֑ד מִ⁠סַּל֙ הַ⁠מַּצּ֔וֹת אֲשֶׁ֖ר לִ⁠פְנֵ֥י יְהוָֽה
notes.note: All of these items were in the basket mentioned in [29:2](../29/02.md), not just the wafer. Be sure this is clear in your translation. Alternate translation: [and from the basket of bread without yeast that is before the face of Yahweh: one round loaf of bread, and one cake of bread of oil, and one wafer]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠כִכַּ֨ר לֶ֜חֶם אַחַ֗ת וַֽ⁠חַלַּ֨ת לֶ֥חֶם שֶׁ֛מֶן אַחַ֖ת וְ⁠רָקִ֣יק אֶחָ֑ד מִ⁠סַּל֙ הַ⁠מַּצּ֔וֹת
notes.note: For [29:23](../29/23.md), see how you translated similar words in [Exodus 29:2](../29/02.md).
This means in the presence of Yahweh. Alternate translation: [that you have placed before Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: Put all these in the hands of Aaron and his sons and wave them before the LORD as a wave offering.
ult_verse_text: And you shall put all these on the palms of Aaron and on the palms of his sons, and you shall raise them as a raised offering before the face of Yahweh.

notes.note: Here, **all these** refers to the parts of the sacrifice mentioned in the previous verses.

While the text reads, **you shall raise**, logically, it is Aaron and his sons who will raise the offerings at this point. If this is confusing in your language, you may use the third person. Alternate translation: [and they shall raise]

The act of raising the meat and bread symbolized dedicating it to Yahweh. The priests would be acting out the process of handing the offering to him. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [and they shall show that they are giving them to me by holding them up to me]
This means in the presence of Yahweh. Alternate translation: [before Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: Then take them from their hands and burn them on the altar atop the burnt offering as a pleasing aroma before the LORD; it is a food offering to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And you shall take them from their hands, and cause them to become smoke on the altar above the burnt offering to be an aroma of appeasing before the face of Yahweh, it is a fire offering to Yahweh.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הִקְטַרְתָּ֥ הַ⁠מִּזְבֵּ֖חָ⁠ה עַל־הָ⁠עֹלָ֑ה לְ⁠רֵ֤יחַ נִיח֨וֹחַ֙ לִ⁠פְנֵ֣י יְהוָ֔ה אִשֶּׁ֥ה ה֖וּא לַ⁠יהוָֽה
notes.note: See how you translated similar phrases in [29:18](../29/18.md).

bsb_verse_text: Take the breast of the ram of Aaron’s ordination and wave it before the LORD as a wave offering, and it will be your portion.
ult_verse_text: And you shall take the breast from the ram of consecration that is for Aaron and raise it for a raised offering before the face of Yahweh, and it will be your share.

notes.note: See how you translated this in [29:22](../29/22.md). Alternate translation: [from the ram that you dedicated]

The act of raising the meat symbolized dedicating it to Yahweh. The priests would be acting out handing the offering to him. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. See how you translated this in [29:24](../29/24.md). Alternate translation: [and show that you are giving it to me by holding it up to me]

bsb_verse_text: Consecrate for Aaron and his sons the breast of the wave offering that is waved and the thigh of the heave offering that is lifted up from the ram of ordination.
ult_verse_text: And from the ram of consecration which is for Aaron and which is for his sons, you shall set apart the breast of the raised offering that was raised and the thigh of the contribution that was contributed.

notes.orig_language_quote: הַ⁠תְּנוּפָ֗ה וְ⁠אֵת֙ שׁ֣וֹק הַ⁠תְּרוּמָ֔ה אֲשֶׁ֥ר הוּנַ֖ף וַ⁠אֲשֶׁ֣ר הוּרָ֑ם
notes.note: The act of raising the meat symbolized dedicating it to Yahweh. The priests would be acting out handing the offering to him. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. See how you translated this in [29:24](../29/24.md).

bsb_verse_text: This will belong to Aaron and his sons as a regular portion from the Israelites, for it is the heave offering the Israelites will make to the LORD from their peace offerings.
ult_verse_text: And it shall belong to Aaron and to his sons—as an eternal requirement—for it is an offering from the sons of Israel. And it shall be an offering from the sons of Israel from the sacrifices of their peace offerings, their offerings to Yahweh.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הָיָה֩ לְ⁠אַהֲרֹ֨ן וּ⁠לְ⁠בָנָ֜י⁠ו לְ⁠חָק־עוֹלָ֗ם מֵ⁠אֵת֙ בְּנֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל כִּ֥י תְרוּמָ֖ה ה֑וּא
notes.note: Alternate translation: [This offering is what Aaron and his sons will always receive from the people]

notes.orig_language_quote: מֵ⁠אֵת֙ בְּנֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל כִּ֥י תְרוּמָ֖ה ה֑וּא וּ⁠תְרוּמָ֞ה יִהְיֶ֨ה מֵ⁠אֵ֤ת בְּנֵֽי־יִשְׂרָאֵל֙ מִ⁠זִּבְחֵ֣י שַׁלְמֵי⁠הֶ֔ם תְּרוּמָתָ֖⁠ם לַ⁠יהוָֽה
notes.note: The amount of repetition in this verse may make it difficult to translate smoothly. You may consider combining some phrases if that would work better in your language. Alternate translation: [for the Israelites must offer this portion from what they bring to Yahweh as peace offerings to him]

bsb_verse_text: The holy garments that belong to Aaron will belong to his sons after him, so they can be anointed and ordained in them.
ult_verse_text: And the garments of holiness that are for Aaron shall be for his sons after him, for anointing in them and to fill their hand in them.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **holiness**, you can express the same idea in another way. See how you translated this in [28:2](../28/02.md).
**Fill their hand** seems to be an idiom for giving authority to someone. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:41](../28/41.md). Alternate translation: [to ordain them in the clothing]

bsb_verse_text: You are to take the ram of ordination and boil its flesh in a holy place.
ult_verse_text: And you shall take the ram of consecration and boil its meat in a holy place.

notes.note: The **ram of consecration** refers to the second ram, the one described in [20:19](../20/19.md) and following.

This is not the same as the Holy Place outside of the Most Holy Place. This probably refers to a place within the courtyard. However, its exact location is not otherwise specified. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [at the entrance to the tent of meeting]

bsb_verse_text: They must eat those things by which atonement was made for their ordination and consecration. But no outsider may eat them, because these things are sacred.
ult_verse_text: And they shall eat these that were for their atoning to fill their hand, to set them apart. But a stranger shall not eat them, because they are set apart.

notes.note: This seems to be an idiom for giving authority to someone. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:41](../28/41.md). Alternate translation: [to ordain them]

bsb_verse_text: And if any of the meat of ordination or any bread is left until the morning, you are to burn up the remainder. It must not be eaten, because it is sacred.
ult_verse_text: And if any meat of the consecration or any of the bread remains until the morning, then you shall burn the remainder with fire. It shall not be eaten, because it is set apart.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [No one may eat it]

bsb_verse_text: This is what you are to do for Aaron and his sons based on all that I have commanded you, taking seven days to ordain them.
ult_verse_text: And thus you shall do to Aaron and to his sons according to all that I have commanded you: you shall fill their hand seven days.

notes.note: Here, **thus** means “like this” and, as the next verses make clear, refers to the sacrificial ceremony outlined in this chapter which they must repeat seven times.
Alternate translation: [7]
This seems to be an idiom for giving authority to someone. See how you translated this in [Exodus 28:41](../28/41.md). Alternate translation: [you shall ordain them]

bsb_verse_text: Sacrifice a bull as a sin offering each day for atonement. Purify the altar by making atonement for it, and anoint it to consecrate it.
ult_verse_text: And you shall offer a bull of purification for atonement daily, and you shall purify the altar by making atonement for it. And you shall anoint it to set it apart.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠פַ֨ר חַטָּ֜את תַּעֲשֶׂ֤ה לַ⁠יּוֹם֙ עַל־הַ⁠כִּפֻּרִ֔ים וְ⁠חִטֵּאתָ֙ עַל־הַ⁠מִּזְבֵּ֔חַ בְּ⁠כַפֶּרְ⁠ךָ֖ עָלָ֑י⁠ו
notes.note: The phrase **and you shall purify the altar by making atonement for it** describes the purpose of offering the bull. You may want to use a stronger connector. In languages that need to put purpose first, you may need to re-order the clauses. Alternate translation: [And you shall offer a bull of purification for atonement daily, thus you shall purify the altar, by making atonement for it.] or [You shall purify the altar by making atonement for it: you shall offer a bull of purification daily for its atonement.]
This verse and the next explain the purpose of the sacrifice detailed in [29:10–14](../29/10.md).

bsb_verse_text: For seven days you shall make atonement for the altar and consecrate it. Then the altar will become most holy; whatever touches the altar will be holy.
ult_verse_text: You shall make atonement for the altar seven days, and set it apart. And the altar will be a holiest holy thing. Whatever touches the altar will be set apart.

notes.note: Here, **holiest holy** means extremely or uniquely holy. If this form would not express that this item would become uniquely holy in your language you may need to find another way to express this idea. Alternate translation: [a most holy thing] or [extraordinarily holy]
Alternate translation: [will also become set apart]

bsb_verse_text: This is what you are to offer regularly on the altar, each day: two lambs that are a year old.
ult_verse_text: And this is what you shall offer on the altar every day continually: two lambs, sons of a year.

notes.note: The phrase **sons of a year** is an idiom meaning one year old. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language.

bsb_verse_text: Offer one lamb in the morning and the other at twilight.
ult_verse_text: The one lamb you shall offer in the morning, and the second lamb you shall offer between the evenings.

notes.note: The exact meaning of this phrase is debated. Since the priests ate many of the sacrifices, it may have been offered around the time of the evening meal.

bsb_verse_text: With the first lamb offer a tenth of an ephah of fine flour, mixed with a quarter hin of oil from pressed olives, and a drink offering of a quarter hin of wine.
ult_verse_text: For the first lamb: a tenth of fine flour mixed with pressed oil (the fourth part of a hin) and a drink offering: the fourth part of a hin of wine.

notes.note: A **tenth** means one part out of ten equal parts. A **fourth** means one part out of four equal parts.

Many commentators suggest that this means one tenth of an “ephah” even though “ephah” is not written. If your translation style retains the original measurement words, you may need to insert the word you are using for “ephah” here.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠עִשָּׂרֹ֨ן סֹ֜לֶת & רֶ֣בַע הַ⁠הִ֔ין & רְבִעִ֥ית הַ⁠הִ֖ין
notes.note: The values given in the UST are approximations as the exact size of an ephah and a hin is not precisely known. An ephah (the implied measurement) may have been around 22 liters, so this is about 2.2 liters of flour. A hin may have been around 3.7 liters, so this is about one liter of both oil and wine.

bsb_verse_text: And offer the second lamb at twilight with the same grain offering and drink offering as in the morning, as a pleasing aroma, a food offering to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And you shall offer the second lamb between the evenings. You shall offer the same grain offering as in the morning and the same drink offering with it for a scent of appeasement, a fire offering to Yahweh.

notes.note: The exact meaning of the phrase **between the evenings** is debated. Since the priests ate many of the sacrifices, it may have been offered around the time of the evening meal. See how you translated it in [29:39](../29/39.md).

bsb_verse_text: For the generations to come, this burnt offering shall be made regularly at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting before the LORD, where I will meet you to speak with you.
ult_verse_text: It shall be a continual burnt offering throughout your generations, at the entrance to the tent of meeting before the face of Yahweh, there where I will meet with you to speak to you there.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [through all the generations of your descendants.] See how you translated this in [Exodus 12:14](../12/14.md).
This means in the presence of Yahweh. Alternate translation: [before Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: I will also meet with the Israelites there, and that place will be consecrated by My glory.
ult_verse_text: And I will meet with the sons of Israel there, and it will be set apart by my glory.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [My awesome presence will dedicate the tent to me]

bsb_verse_text: “You are also to make an altar of acacia wood for the burning of incense.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make an altar, a place of burning of incense. You shall make it with wood of acacias,

notes.note: Here, **you** refers to Moses and the people of Israel. If your language makes a distinction, use a plural form here.

bsb_verse_text: It is to be square, a cubit long, a cubit wide, and two cubits high. Its horns must be of one piece.
ult_verse_text: Its length shall be one cubit and its width shall be one cubit. It shall be square, and its height shall be two cubits. Its horns {shall be} part of it.

notes.note: See how you translated **horns** in [Exodus 27:2](../27/02.md)

If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurements, either in the text or a footnote. A **cubit** is approximately 46cm. For your reference, a more precise conversion to metric is: 46cm … 46cm … 92cm

bsb_verse_text: Overlay with pure gold the top and all the sides and horns, and make a molding of gold around it.
ult_verse_text: And you shall overlay it with pure gold—its top and all around its sides and its horns—and you shall make for it a border of gold around it.

notes.note: This verse is very similar to [Exodus 25:11](../25/11.md), so see how you translated there.

bsb_verse_text: And make two gold rings below the molding on opposite sides to hold the poles used to carry it.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make two rings of gold for it under its border on its two sides. You shall make them on its two sides. They will be housings for the poles for carrying it with.

notes.note: When translating this verse, you may want to refer back to several other passages regarding making rings for carrying poles. See [25:12](../25/12.md), [25:26](../25/26.md), [25:27](../25/27.md), and [27:4](../27/04.md).

This means the people both decided to gather and were the ones gathering. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate this.

**Arise** strengthens the force of the command following it. The people were demanding that Aaron make an idol for them. It did not necessarily mean that he should literally stand up. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language.
Here, **before our faces** means ahead of. The Israelites want idols to lead them. Alternate translation: [shall lead us] or [shall be our leader]

People showed disrespect by putting the word **this** before his name, as if Moses were someone they did not know and could not trust. They were creating social distance between him and themselves. When translating, use a form in your language that communicates the same sense of disassociation between people.

bsb_verse_text: So Aaron told them, “Take off the gold earrings that are on your wives and sons and daughters, and bring them to me.”
ult_verse_text: And Aaron said to them, “Tear off the rings of gold that are on the ears of your wives, your sons, and your daughters and bring them to me.”

notes.note: Here, **them** refers to the golden rings.

bsb_verse_text: Then all the people took off their gold earrings and brought them to Aaron.
ult_verse_text: And all the people tore the rings of gold off themselves that were on their ears and brought them to Aaron.

notes.note: This refers to all the people who rejected Moses as their leader and Yahweh as their God. Later parts of the text reveal that there were people still faithful to Moses and Yahweh and that the Israelites had a great deal more gold. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language that means many or most. Alternate translation: [many people]

bsb_verse_text: He took the gold from their hands, and with an engraving tool he fashioned it into a molten calf. And they said, “These, O Israel, are your gods, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt!”
ult_verse_text: And he took it from their hand, and fashioned it with a tool, and he made a calf of molten metal. And they said, “These are your gods, Israel, who brought you up from the land of Egypt.”

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יָּ֤צַר אֹת⁠וֹ֙ בַּ⁠חֶ֔רֶט וַֽ⁠יַּעֲשֵׂ֖⁠הוּ עֵ֣גֶל מַסֵּכָ֑ה
notes.note: Most likely this means that Aaron melted the gold and poured it into a mold that had the shape of a calf. When the gold cooled and became hard, he removed the mold, and the hardened gold had the shape of a calf.
The identity of the speakers, referred to as **they**, remains unknown. Alternate translation: [And someone said]

Because the speaker of this sentence is unknown and mentioned in the plural, it is possible that it is the people speaking. In that case, it would be possible for a translation to use the first person rather than second person here. Alternate translation: [These are our gods … brought us up]

In the text, there only appears to be one “god” (the golden calf idol) presented to Israel. If it would be clearer to your audience, you may consider translating **these … gods** as singular. Alternate translation: [this is your god]

bsb_verse_text: When Aaron saw this, he built an altar before the calf and proclaimed: “Tomorrow shall be a feast to the LORD.”
ult_verse_text: And Aaron saw, and he built an altar before the face of it, and Aaron proclaimed and said, “Tomorrow will be a festival to Yahweh.”

notes.note: If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express what he saw explicitly. “Aaron saw what the people did”
Here, **before its face** means in front of. Alternate translation: [in front of it]
Here, **it** is the golden bull-calf. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express that explicitly. Alternate translation: [in front of the bull-calf idol]

bsb_verse_text: So the next day they arose, offered burnt offerings, and presented peace offerings. And the people sat down to eat and drink and got up to indulge in revelry.
ult_verse_text: And they arose early the next day and offered burnt offerings and brought peace offerings. And the people sat down to eat and to drink and got up to play.

notes.note: This word may imply drunken and sexual sin (for a sexual implication see [Genesis 26:8](../../gen/26/08.md)). However, the only actions mentioned in the text are singing ([v. 18](../32/18.md)) and dancing ([v. 19](../32/19.md)), so translators should avoid using a term that is overly suggestive. Alternate translation: [to revel]

bsb_verse_text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Go down at once, for your people, whom you brought up out of the land of Egypt, have corrupted themselves.
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh spoke to Moses, “Go! Descend! For your people, whom you brought up from the land of Egypt, have corrupted themselves.

notes.note: Here there is a scene shift back to the top of the mountain with Moses and Yahweh, which may need to be marked in a certain way in your language.

Here, **themselves** is used to indicate that the Israelites actions made the Israelites corrupt. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate this. Alternate translation: [have acted corruptly]

bsb_verse_text: How quickly they have turned aside from the way that I commanded them! They have made for themselves a molten calf and have bowed down to it. They have sacrificed to it and said, ‘These, O Israel, are your gods, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt.’”
ult_verse_text: They have quickly turned from the way that I commanded them. They have made a calf of molten metal for themselves and have bowed before it and sacrificed to it. And they have said, ‘These are your gods, Israel, that brought you up from the land of Egypt.’”

notes.note: Here God speaks of the people disobeying what he commanded them as if he had told them to walk on a certain road, and they left that road. If your readers would not understand what this image means in this context, you could use an equivalent metaphor from your culture. Alternatively, you could express the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [They have quickly stopped doing what I commanded them to do] or [They have quickly stopped obeying what I commanded them to do]

notes.orig_language_quote: אֵ֤לֶּה אֱלֹהֶ֨י⁠ךָ֙ יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל אֲשֶׁ֥ר הֶֽעֱל֖וּ⁠ךָ מֵ⁠אֶ֥רֶץ מִצְרָֽיִם
notes.note: This is a second-level direct quotation. It may be helpful to your readers to indicate this by marking it with second-level quotation marks or with whatever other punctuation or convention your language uses to indicate a quotation within a quotation.

notes.orig_language_quote: אֵ֤לֶּה אֱלֹהֶ֨י⁠ךָ֙ יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל אֲשֶׁ֥ר הֶֽעֱל֖וּ⁠ךָ מֵ⁠אֶ֥רֶץ מִצְרָֽיִם
notes.note: You may want to translate this as an indirect quotation in order to reduce the layers of quotations in this passage. Alternate translation: [that these are your gods, Israel, that brought you up from the land of Egypt]

In the text, there only appears to be one “god” (the golden calf idol) presented to Israel. If it would be clearer to your audience, you may consider translating **these … gods** as singular. See how you translated this in [32:4](../32/04.md). Alternate translation: [This is your god]

Because the speaker of this sentence is unknown and mentioned in the plural, it is possible that it is the people speaking. In that case, it would be possible for a translation to use the first person rather than second person here. See how you translated this in [32:4](../32/04.md). Alternate translation: [our gods … brought us up]

bsb_verse_text: The LORD also said to Moses, “I have seen this people, and they are indeed a stiff-necked people.
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh said to Moses, “I have seen this people, and behold, it is a people hard of neck.

notes.note: Yahweh speaks of the people being rebellious as if they had hard necks. The image comes from an animal that does not want to go the way his master is trying to direct him (not going in the way God commanded). If your readers would not understand what this image means in this context, you could use an equivalent metaphor from your culture. Alternatively, you could express the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [is a rebellious people]

The word **people** is a collective noun, so the pronouns referring to the people are singular. You may use plural pronouns if that is the normal usage in your language. Alternate translation: [these … they]

bsb_verse_text: Now leave Me alone, so that My anger may burn against them and consume them. Then I will make you into a great nation.”
ult_verse_text: So now, leave me alone! And let my nose burn against them, and I will destroy them. And I will make you into a great nation.”

notes.note: **So now** is used here to mark that Yahweh’s next statements are a result of what he has said in the previous verses. Alternate translation: [Therefore]
This is an idiom meaning that Yahweh is angry. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [And let me be angry with them]
Here, **you** refers to Moses.

bsb_verse_text: But Moses sought the favor of the LORD his God, saying, “O LORD, why does Your anger burn against Your people, whom You brought out of the land of Egypt with great power and a mighty hand?
ult_verse_text: But Moses entreated the face of Yahweh his God. And he said, “Yahweh, why does your nose burn against your people whom you have brought out from the land of Egypt with great power and with a strong hand?

notes.orig_language_quote: לָ⁠מָ֤ה יְהוָה֙ יֶחֱרֶ֤ה אַפְּ⁠ךָ֙ בְּ⁠עַמֶּ֔⁠ךָ אֲשֶׁ֤ר הוֹצֵ֨אתָ֙ מֵ⁠אֶ֣רֶץ מִצְרַ֔יִם בְּ⁠כֹ֥חַ גָּד֖וֹל וּ⁠בְ⁠יָ֥ד חֲזָקָֽה
notes.note: Moses used this question to try to persuade Yahweh not to be so angry with his people. If you would not use a rhetorical question for this purpose in your language, you could translate his words as a statement or an exclamation and communicate the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [Yahweh, do not let your nose burn against your people whom you have brought out from the land of Egypt with great power and with a strong hand.]

This is an idiom meaning that Yahweh is angry with his people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [are you angry with your people]

These two phrases share similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. If doubling in this way would not convey emphasis in your language, you will need to find a way to translate it that does give emphasis. Alternate translation: [using your very strong power]
Here, **hand** represents God’s actions or works. See how you translated this in [Exodus 6:1](../06/01.md). Alternate translation: [and with powerful works]

bsb_verse_text: Why should the Egyptians declare, ‘He brought them out with evil intent, to kill them in the mountains and wipe them from the face of the earth’? Turn from Your fierce anger and relent from doing harm to Your people.
ult_verse_text: Why should the Egyptians say, saying, ‘He brought them out with evil intent, to kill them in the mountains and to destroy them from on the face of the ground’? Turn from your burning nose and repent from the evil to your people.

notes.orig_language_quote: לָ⁠מָּה֩ יֹאמְר֨וּ מִצְרַ֜יִם לֵ⁠אמֹ֗ר בְּ⁠רָעָ֤ה הֽוֹצִיאָ⁠ם֙ לַ⁠הֲרֹ֤ג אֹתָ⁠ם֙ בֶּֽ⁠הָרִ֔ים וּ֨⁠לְ⁠כַלֹּתָ֔⁠ם מֵ⁠עַ֖ל פְּנֵ֣י הָֽ⁠אֲדָמָ֑ה
notes.note: Moses used this question to try to persuade God not to destroy his people. If you would not use a rhetorical question for this purpose in your language, you could translate his words as a statement or an exclamation and communicate the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [If you destroy your people, the Egyptians might say, ‘He brought them out with evil intent, to kill them in the mountains and to destroy them from on the face of the ground.’]

notes.orig_language_quote: יֹאמְר֨וּ מִצְרַ֜יִם לֵ⁠אמֹ֗ר בְּ⁠רָעָ֤ה הֽוֹצִיאָ⁠ם֙ לַ⁠הֲרֹ֤ג אֹתָ⁠ם֙ בֶּֽ⁠הָרִ֔ים וּ֨⁠לְ⁠כַלֹּתָ֔⁠ם מֵ⁠עַ֖ל פְּנֵ֣י הָֽ⁠אֲדָמָ֑ה
notes.note: After **saying,** this is a second-level quotation. It may be helpful to your readers to indicate this with second-level quotation marks or with whatever other punctuation or convention your language uses to indicate a quotation within a quotation. However, you may want to translate this as an indirect quotation in order to reduce the layers of quotations in this passage. Alternate translation: [the Egyptians say that you brought them out with evil intent, to kill them in the mountains and to destroy them from on the face of the ground]
Here, **face** means “surface.” Alternate translation: [from the surface of the land] or [from the earth]
Alternate translation: [Stop your burning anger] or [Stop being so angry]

notes.orig_language_quote: שׁ֚וּב מֵ⁠חֲר֣וֹן אַפֶּ֔⁠ךָ וְ⁠הִנָּחֵ֥ם עַל־הָ⁠רָעָ֖ה לְ⁠עַמֶּֽ⁠ךָ
notes.note: Here, Yahweh’s anger (burning nose) and plan to punish the people are spoken of as things that he could turn away from and repent of (repentance also means to turn from). This imagery may not translate into your language, and you may need to use a different expression. Alternate translation: [Calm down, and please do not stay determined to do evil to your people]
This is an idiom that means anger. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [from your terrible anger]

bsb_verse_text: Remember Your servants Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, to whom You swore by Your very self when You declared, ‘I will make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky, and I will give your descendants all this land that I have promised, and it shall be their inheritance forever.’”
ult_verse_text: Remember Abraham and Isaac and Israel, your servants that you swore to them by yourself and spoke to them, ‘I will cause your descendants to increase as the stars of the heavens, and I will give to your descendants all this land of which I have spoken. And they will inherit it forever.’”

notes.note: Alternate translation: [Think about]
Alternate translation: [you made an oath]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠כָל־הָ⁠אָ֨רֶץ הַ⁠זֹּ֜את אֲשֶׁ֣ר אָמַ֗רְתִּי אֶתֵּן֙ לְ⁠זַרְעֲ⁠כֶ֔ם
notes.note: That is, the land of Canaan.

bsb_verse_text: Then Moses turned and went down the mountain with the two tablets of the Testimony in his hands. They were inscribed on both sides, front and back.
ult_verse_text: And Moses turned and went down from the mountain and the two tablets of the testimony {were} in his hand. The tablets were written on both their sides, on this {side} and on that {side} they were written.

notes.orig_language_quote: לֻחֹ֗ת כְּתֻבִים֙ מִ⁠שְּׁנֵ֣י עֶבְרֵי⁠הֶ֔ם מִ⁠זֶּ֥ה וּ⁠מִ⁠זֶּ֖ה הֵ֥ם כְּתֻבִֽים
notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Yahweh had written on both the sides of the tablets, on this side and on that side he had written.]

bsb_verse_text: The tablets were the work of God, and the writing was the writing of God, engraved on the tablets.
ult_verse_text: And the tablets, they {were} the work of God. And the writing, it {was} the writing of God, {it} was engraved on the tablets.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הַ֨⁠לֻּחֹ֔ת מַעֲשֵׂ֥ה אֱלֹהִ֖ים הֵ֑מָּה וְ⁠הַ⁠מִּכְתָּ֗ב מִכְתַּ֤ב אֱלֹהִים֙ ה֔וּא
notes.note: These two sentences have an unusual structure that places emphasis on **tablets** and **writing**. If your language would emphasize these topics in a different way than moving them to the beginning of the sentence, follow your language’s natural usage for emphasis. Alternate translation: [And the tablets themselves were the work of God. And the writing itself was the writing of God]

bsb_verse_text: When Joshua heard the sound of the people shouting, he said to Moses, “The sound of war is in the camp.”
ult_verse_text: And Joshua heard the noise of the people in its shouting, and he said to Moses, “{There is} the noise of war in the camp.”

notes.note: Joshua was last mentioned in [Exodus 24:13](../24/13.md). The text does not say if he was on top of the mountain with Moses or if he waited for him part way up. Consider if your language will need to re-introduce Joshua in any way here.

bsb_verse_text: But Moses replied: “It is neither the cry of victory nor the cry of defeat; I hear the sound of singing!”
ult_verse_text: But Moses said,

notes.orig_language_quote: אֵ֥ין קוֹל֙ עֲנ֣וֹת גְּבוּרָ֔ה וְ⁠אֵ֥ין ק֖וֹל עֲנ֣וֹת חֲלוּשָׁ֑ה ק֣וֹל עַנּ֔וֹת אָנֹכִ֖י שֹׁמֵֽעַ
notes.note: These lines are widely considered to be poetic. It is not clear why a poetic form is used here. In some languages it may not be appropriate to convey this response in poetic form, in which case another form may be used.

notes.orig_language_quote: אֵ֥ין קוֹל֙ עֲנ֣וֹת גְּבוּרָ֔ה וְ⁠אֵ֥ין ק֖וֹל עֲנ֣וֹת חֲלוּשָׁ֑ה ק֣וֹל עַנּ֔וֹת אָנֹכִ֖י שֹׁמֵֽעַ
notes.note: The poetic form here is parallelism in the repetition of **sound of singing**. If it would be unclear to say that Moses heard **the sound of singing** in the third line after saying he did not hear the sound of singing twice before, something more like the more contrastive UST may be followed.

If it is unclear to say that Moses hears **the sound of singing** after twice saying he did not hear that, you may want to make the type of singing explicit. Consider referring to your translation of the last word of [32:6](../32/06.md) (to play in the ULT). Alternate translation: [the sound of playful singing I hear]

bsb_verse_text: As Moses approached the camp and saw the calf and the dancing, he burned with anger and threw the tablets out of his hands, shattering them at the base of the mountain.
ult_verse_text: And it happened, as he approached to the camp, that he saw the calf and dancing, and the nose of Moses burned, and he threw the tablets from his hands and shattered them under the mountain.

notes.note: This is an idiom for being angry. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [and Moses was very angry]
Alternate translation: [at the bottom of]

bsb_verse_text: “What did this people do to you,” Moses asked Aaron, “that you have led them into so great a sin?”
ult_verse_text: And Moses said to Aaron, “What did this people do to you, that you have brought a great sin on them?”

notes.note: Moses spoke of causing people to **sin** as if sin were an object and Aaron put it **on them**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [that you have caused them to sin greatly]

bsb_verse_text: “Do not be enraged, my lord,” Aaron replied. “You yourself know that the people are intent on evil.
ult_verse_text: And Aaron said, “Do not let {your} nose burn, my lord. You know the people, that it {is/was} in evil.

notes.note: This is an idiom for anger. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [Do not be angry]

This is probably an idiom that could mean (1) that the people are prone to evil or (2) that the people were in trouble (that is, they felt troubled because of not having contact with God). If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [that they are set on evil]
Here, **it** is used because **people** is grammatically singular in Hebrew. Alternate translation: [they are]

bsb_verse_text: They told me, ‘Make us gods who will go before us. As for this Moses who brought us up out of the land of Egypt, we do not know what has happened to him!’
ult_verse_text: And they said to me, ‘Make for us a god that will go before our faces. As for this Moses, the man that brought us up from the land of Egypt, we do not know what has happened to him.’

notes.orig_language_quote: עֲשֵׂה־לָ֣⁠נוּ אֱלֹהִ֔ים אֲשֶׁ֥ר יֵלְכ֖וּ לְ⁠פָנֵ֑י⁠נוּ כִּי־זֶ֣ה ׀ מֹשֶׁ֣ה הָ⁠אִ֗ישׁ אֲשֶׁ֤ר הֶֽעֱלָ֨⁠נוּ֙ מֵ⁠אֶ֣רֶץ מִצְרַ֔יִם לֹ֥א יָדַ֖עְנוּ מֶה־הָ֥יָה לֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: This is a second-level quotation. It may be helpful to your readers to indicate this with second-level quotation marks or with whatever other punctuation or convention your language uses to indicate a quotation within a quotation.

People showed disrespect by putting the word **this** before his name, as if Moses were someone they did not know and could not trust. They were creating social distance between him and themselves. When translating, use a form in your language that communicates the same sense of disassociation between people. See how you translated this in [32:1](../32/01.md).

bsb_verse_text: So I said to them, ‘Whoever has gold, let him take it off,’ and they gave it to me. And when I threw it into the fire, out came this calf!”
ult_verse_text: And I said to them, ‘Whoever has gold, take it off yourself.’ And they gave {it} to me, and I threw it in the fire, and this calf came out.”

notes.note: **Whoever has gold, take it off yourself** is a second-level quotation. It may be helpful to your readers to indicate this with second-level quotation marks or with whatever other punctuation or convention your language uses to indicate a quotation within a quotation. However, this can be stated as an indirect quote. Alternate translation: [So I told them that whoever had any gold should take it off]
Aaron instructs people to take their own gold off. Alternate translation: [you take off your own]

Aaron claims an unusual sequence of events here. The translation should surprise an audience unfamiliar with the story. He states that the result of simply throwing gold in the fire is the appearance (by its own power or volition it seems) of the calf. This is a lie.

bsb_verse_text: Moses saw that the people were out of control, for Aaron had let them run wild and become a laughingstock to their enemies.
ult_verse_text: And Moses saw the people, that it was let loose, for Aaron had let it loose, to mockery by the risers-up against them.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [were behaving wildly] or [were not controlling themselves]

Here, the pronoun **it** agrees with the grammatical number of **people** (singular). If your language does not use singular nouns in that way, you can use a different expression. Alternate translation: [that they were let loose, for Aaron had let them loose]

bsb_verse_text: So Moses stood at the entrance to the camp and said, “Whoever is for the LORD, come to me.” And all the Levites gathered around him.
ult_verse_text: And Moses stood in the gate of the camp and said, “Who {is} for Yahweh, to me!” And all of the sons of Levi gathered themselves to him.

notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: [and said that whoever was for Yahweh should come to him]

Moses speaks of being loyal to Yahweh as being **for Yahweh**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent idiom or use plain language. Alternate translation: [Whoever serves Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: He told them, “This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: ‘Each of you men is to fasten his sword to his side, go back and forth through the camp from gate to gate, and slay his brother, his friend, and his neighbor.’”
ult_verse_text: And he said to them, “Thus says Yahweh, the God of Israel: ‘Each man put his sword on his side. Pass through and return from gate to gate in the camp and kill each his brother and each his companion and each his neighbor.’”

notes.note: Alternate translation: [Go from one side of the camp to the other, starting at one entrance to the camp and going to the entrance on the other side of the camp]

bsb_verse_text: The Levites did as Moses commanded, and that day about three thousand of the people fell dead.
ult_verse_text: And the sons of Levi did according to the word of Moses. And on that day about 3, 000 men from the people fell.
